Controversy Explanation: After the college revoked a past invitation to Falkoff due to security issues, Falkoff's rescheduled appearance caused controversy. Falkoff, again, received anonymous threats of violence against him and his family, but he spoke successfully.
Students protested the university's invitation of McCain to deliver a commencement speech because of McCain's support for an Arizona immigration law. McCain spoke successfully.

The college banned performances of the play, The Vagina Monologues, on campus in 2006 because "its depiction of female sexuality is so deeply at odds with the true meaning and morality that the Catholic Church’s teaching celebrates." Students performed the play off campus for the fourth year straight.
Graduating seniors opposed Sambi's invitation to speak at commencement, claiming Sambi verbally "attacked" a gay pride festival and a clergy abuse victim. Sambi spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Content of Expression. The university's Director of Communications statement included: "During his time in the Middle East, Archbishop Sambi was also a passionate advocate for Catholics - a minority in that region of the world. He used his skills not only to aid his Church, but also to fight for the rights of all the Christian faithful to have access to the Holy Land."

School: Seton Hall University School of Law
Controversy Explanation: Some faculty and alumni opposed the university's invitation of Christie to deliver a commencement speech because of Christie's decision not to reappoint Associate Justice John Wallace to the state Supreme Court. Christie spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The law school dean said: "The school intends to go ahead with the graduation, as planned . . . .Our intention is not to politicize our graduation in any way."

Controversy Explanation: Administrators rejected a student's drawing depicting three professors from the college's fourth annual Women’s History Month Street Painting Festival and Community Resource Fair, claiming it was "controversial" and did not fit into the "theme" of the festival.

School: State University of New York, Oswego
Controversy Explanation: Students opposed McHugh due to his support for "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" U.S. military policy. McHugh withdrew from delivering the commencement address, saying he didn't want the commencement ceremony to be disrupted.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The university president said: "People of good will hold diverse opinions on the issues that matter in our society. We are obligated to inform ourselves on the issues, to speak our minds with civility and to listen to opposing views with respect."

Controversy Explanation: Students wrote an op-ed and students and professors protested to try to get the university to choose a different commencement speaker, objecting to the fact that Dimon is a wealthy financier. Dimon spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral. The university chancellor said: "I fully understand these students' distress and I embrace their right to protest, however, [the university] is not rescinding Dimon's invitation."

Controversy Explanation: A professor canceled four student-directed plays scheduled to take place on the same day after administrators received hundreds of emails and calls, some of them threatening, demanding that it cancel Corpus Christi, a play which depicts Jesus Christ as a gay man. The state's lieutenant governor also called on the university to cancel the performance.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as Person, Appeased Protesters, Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship.The university president said: "As  a  public  university  we  are  legally  bound  to  allow  the  student  production to  go  forward. We  have  had  many  conversations  with  the  Office  of  General  Counsel  for  The  Texas  A&M  University  System  and  they  have  made  it  clear  to  us  that  this  is  an  unambiguous  freedom  of  speech  (First  Amendment)  issue. . . . [But m]y personal reaction is that I see no artistic or redeeming quality in the work. I believe, as many have opined, that it is offensive, crude, and irreverent," he wrote. "It is my sense that there are significant numbers of faculty, staff and students at Tarleton who share my views of the play. "

Controversy Explanation: A professor canceled four student-directed plays scheduled to take place on the same day after university administrators received hundreds emails and calls, some of them threatening, demanding that it cancel Corpus Christi, a play which depicts Jesus Christ as a gay man. The state's lieutenant governor also called on the university to cancel the performance. The play, The Importance of Being Earnest, was also canceled despite the fact that it was not the target of the calls for cancellation.
Soto was heckled and jeered throughout her speech because of her criticism of the Arizona immigration law, with some students shouting at her to cut her hair. She finished her talk.

School: University of Arizona College of Law
Controversy Explanation: Vogt, a third year law student, was voted by his classmates to be one of the commencement speakers that year. Vogt was then appointed to the Arizona State House of Representatives where he voted in favor of two controversial immigration bills that some law students considered racist. Law students started a petition to demand that Vogt step down as a commencement speaker. Vogt spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Neutral: The dean of the law school issued a statement: "If he chooses, Mr. Vogt, as one of the two student-elected speakers, will address the class as planned. Others may choose to express their disapproval in some fashion.

In my judgment, there is no appropriate institutional position but to respect these choices, and we do. I would, however, encourage each of you (as I have the students with whom I have already spoken) to bear in mind, and be respectful of, the fundamental reason that we are joining together with your family and friends on May 15."

Controversy Explanation: Students and audience members heckled the Israeli ambassador due to his pro-Israel views. Eleven students were arrested for disruptions and 10 of them were subsequently convicted. Oren cut his remarks short.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The chair of the sponsoring department stated while introduced Oren: “[W]e expect and we relish spirited discussion…but we also have the highest expectation for civility and respect.”

Controversy Explanation: Students protested Rove and heckled him during his speech due to his role in forming Iraq and Afghanistan war policy. Rove finished his remarks.

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation to Keehan because of her support for the Affordable Care Act that "severely damaged pro-life efforts in this nation and undermined the express will of the U.S. bishops." Keehan spoke successfully.
University administrators revoked Ayers' invitation, claiming his militant past with the Weather Underground created security concerns. Ayers sued, won the lawsuit, and ultimately appeared on campus.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. The university president said that "The University of Wyoming is one of the few institutions remaining in today's environment that garners the confidence of the public. The visit by Professor Ayers would have adversely impacted that reputation."

Controversy Explanation: The university received complaints from the local community suggesting it should disinvite Glover over his ties to Hugo Chavez. Glover spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The university president's statement included: "Glover is a distinguished actor and the university is honored to have him speak. . . . Glover's advocacy for social justice and ties to the university are reasons for awarding him an honorary doctorate in humane letters.

Controversy Explanation: Alumni and community members objected to Ayers' past militant activity. College administrators canceled the event.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. A news article reported that university administrators refused to allow the Ayers to either visit or teleconference "out of concern for the safety and well-being of our students and respect for the local community where the alleged actions of the Weather Underground continue to reverberate today."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and called on its members and other concerned Catholics to encourage the college to cancel the performance. The event took place.

Students from Brandeis, Bentley College, Babson College and Holy Cross College opposed Ayers' speech at Brandeis because of Ayers' past affiliation with the Weather Underground. Brandeis students unsuccessfully attempted to prevent the undergraduate student government from funding the speech. During and before the speech students and community members protested outside the auditorium. Ayers completed his remarks.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. An article reported: "A Brandeis spokesman said the university does not endorse Ayer’s appearance, but won’t stop it."

Controversy Explanation: The university president disinvited Finkelstein from a speaking event, claiming the event conflicted with plans to host a Holocaust remembrance event that same week. Finkelstein was reinvited and spoke successfully on campus a few weeks later.
Public Response: Encouraged (Approved of) Self-Censorship. The university president said: "My decision in this case was based solely on the unfortunate timing of the proposed talk. I have not banned Norman Finkelstein from ever speaking on campus. I have asked for some campus reflection on the issues raised by the controversy, that is what if any boundaries govern invitations to speakers on campus and what if any scheduling concerns are legitimate."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and called on its members and other concerned Catholics to encourage the college to cancel the performance. The event took place.

Shrybman, an Israeli citizen, planned to bring a rocket that had landed near his home to campus. After students signed a letter to the administration opposing his bringing the rocket, he did not bring it. The university shut down the speaking event after severe disruptions by anti-Israel activists, and security escorted Shrybman out of the building.
Students and administrators tried to cancel Sharansky's speech because of his pro-Israel views. Sharansky spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and called on its members and other concerned Catholics to encourage the university to cancel the performance. The event took place.
Students objected to the invitation of Ayers and a conservative blogger petitioned the university, objecting to the invitation of Ayers. Ayers spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university president said "FSU is a strong proponent of free speech and has a history of appearances by controversial speakers."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and provided a sample letter on its website that included the contact information of the university's president. Student Affairs did not approve the performance, so the student organizers held it off campus instead.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and called on its members and other concerned Catholics to encourage the university to cancel the performance. The event took place.

Controversy Topic(s): Criminal or Other Misconduct, Political Views, Terrorism
Controversy Explanation: Students, alumni, and parents objected to Ayers' ties to former President Obama and the Weather Underground. The university canceled the event, claiming it did so due to security costs.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said the event was canceled because it would have required "securing a major facility and the closing of several major parking lots that would disrupt university operations.”

Controversy Explanation: Students protested Gilchrist's founding of an anti-illegal immigration group. The group that hosted Gilchrist disinvited him from a panel on immigration.
The annual drag show was was postponed by university administrators for the year due its "controversial nature" and because the performance conflicted with Ignatian Heritage Week.
Public Response: Condemned the Content of the Expresion: The university's Vice President for Student Affairs said that: “Prior shows included professionals who led discussions, answered questions and addressed myths and stereotypes. This year’s event was to be sponsored by the SUPB, did not explicitly include these elements and was to feature current students in drag performing karaoke. Unless the context for a drag show is clearly articulated and includes an educational purpose, there is a distinct possibility that the show could result in the objectification of women and men as well as stereotyping of GLBT persons. [This would] contravene the core values of John Carroll, intentionally or unintentionally."

Controversy Explanation: A bishop of the Pennsylvania diocese demanded that the college disinivite Casey from delivering a commencement speech because although Casey said he is anti-abortion, he voted to confirm a Secretary of Health who was pro-choice. Casey spoke successfully at commencement.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and called on its members and other concerned Catholics to encourage the university to cancel the performance. The event took place.
The university banned the play, The Vagina Monologues,from campus in 2006. Students performed the play off-campus for the second year straight.

A student organization, the Student Peace Action Network, invited Falkoff to speak on campus. Falkoff faced opposition and received anonymous threats of violence against him and his family due to his representation of Gitmo detainees. The school, expecting mass protests of the event, claimed security issues. The event was rescheduled for the next semester and was protested by outside groups.
Public Response: Neutral. The college president told reporters: "Officials believed they were not ready for the crowds and want more time to prepare. . . . We're not canceling, we are just postponing it for a later date. We will make sure we have done the necessary preparations."

Controversy Topic(s): Criminal or Other Misconduct, Political Views, Terrorism
Controversy Explanation: State lawmakers and some students pressured the university to cancel Ayers' speech because of his past involvement in the Weather Underground. Millersville refused to drop the invitation. Some nondisruptive protests occurred while Ayers delivered his remarks.
Public Response: Neutral. A university spokesperson said that the "March 19 event is expected to go on as scheduled . . .  Ayers' supporters see it as a matter of academic freedom, while his detractors say his background will hurt the school's reputation."

Controversy Explanation: Student groups objected to Darwish's views on Islam, and the student group who invited her claimed not to have been fully aware of her views and rescinded the invitation. Darwish was reinvited by a different student group the next year.

The college banned performances of the play, The Vagina Monologues, on campus in 2006 because "its depiction of female sexuality is so deeply at odds with the true meaning and morality that the Catholic Church’s teaching celebrates." Students performed the play off campus for the third year straight.
The university, objecting to Horowitz's views on Islam, did not ban Horowitz' talk outright, but it demanded so many modifications that the College Republicans canceled the event.
Public Response: Encouraged (Approved of) Self-Censorship.  A university issued statement explained: "University officials expressed concern that the program in its current form could be viewed as attacking another faith and seeking to cause derision on campus. . . . Believing that this was not their intent, University officials offered the students several suggestions to modify their program in a way that could achieve their aims while remaining true to the university's Catholic, Jesuit mission and values."

Controversy Explanation: Shrybman, an Israeli citizen, was planning to talk about the effects of war on the Israeli people. SLU Jews, the event host, canceled the event, fearing protests after Shrybman was forced off-campus at DePaul University.

A student group called Concerned Saint Mary's Students sent a letter to students and donors protesting the college's invitation of Ayers because of Ayers' past involvement in the Weather Underground. Students protested at the event, but Ayers spoke despite interruptions.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The college provost said the lecture was set up "to explore it [educational reform] in a context that values critical debate and vigorous examination of ideas, which is something we pride ourselves on doing at St. Mary's."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and called on its members and other concerned Catholics to encourage the university to cancel the performance. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and called on its members and other concerned Catholics to encourage the university to cancel the performance. The event took place.
Students requested that the university disinvite Wilders because of Wilders' views regarding Muslims. Wilders ended his speech early due students shouting threats.
Officials from the San Francisco chinese government consulate asked the university to cancel a talk by the Dalai Lama. The university refused to cancel the talk and the Dalai Lama spoke successfully.
Students formed a group on social media to stop Franco from speaking at commencement, arguing Franco was not "serious" or "experienced" enough. Franco withdrew because of a scheduling conflict.

School: University of California, Los Angeles, Anderson School of Management
Controversy Explanation: Alumni and activist organizations, including Human Rights Watch and Equality California, opposed Whitman's invitation to speak at commencement because of her support for Proposition 8, which banned same-sex marriage in California, and asked the university to rescind Whitman's invitation. The dean of the management school refused to rescind Whitman's invitation. Whitman withdrew from speaking at commencement because of "scheduling conflicts."

Pro-Palestinian students objected to former Israeli Prime Minister Olmert and heckled him almost nonstop throughout his speech. At one point, Olmert pleaded to be able to speak for five minutes without interruption. Security removed a total of 20-30 students at various times during the speech, one of whom was arrested. Olmert ultimately completed his remarks.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The university's official statement included: “Any stifling of debate runs counter to the primary values of the University of Chicago and to our long-standing position as an exemplar of academic freedom. . . . If anybody attempts to disrupt a public event or prevent an invited guest or other recognized speaker from being heard, we will ask that this behavior stop. If that warning is not heeded, we may remove any members of the audience creating the disruption."

Controversy Explanation: Pro-Palestine students protested and heckled Olmert, the former Israeli prime minister, but he spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as Person (Not Views). A university spokesperson said that because of "his [Olmert's] status as a world leader, we felt his perspective would be beneficial . . . so we invited him to visit."

Controversy Explanation: The university canceled a student-run campus event that included a presentation by Planned Parenthood followed by a screening of a pornographic film, Pirates II: Stagnetti's Revenge. It did so after an amendment to a budget bill was introduced in the Maryland Senate that would strip any public higher education institution of funding for sponsoring, sanctioning, promoting, endorsing, or allowing a public screening of any film marketed as an XXX-rated adult film unless it screens the film as part of an official academic course offering open only to students enrolled in that course.
Public Response: Neutral, Appeased Protesters. A university statement said: "[The opportunity to] engage students in a discussion about the national dialogue revolving around pornography got lost in the titillation revolving around the film's showing."

Controversy Explanation: The College Republicans protested the university's invitation of Churchill because of Churchill's comments about 9/11 victims. A state legislator also said that the university could jeopardize its funding by allowing Churchill to speak. Churchill delivered his speech.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university president said that he found Churchill's views "personally offensive, wildly inaccurate and remarkably hurtful to those who lost loved ones there on that day."

Controversy Explanation: Members of the audience heckled Coulter, objecting to her conservative views. University public safety officers removed six people from the event. Coulter finished delivering her remarks.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. A local bishop also opposed the performance and questioned whether academic freedom was a proper rationale for hosting the play. The event took place.
Public Response: None. A university spokesman said: "We appreciate the Bishop's point of view, but we have no additional comment."

Controversy Explanation: The university revoked Churchill's invitation to be a keynote speaker at a conference on race and immigration, fearing that Churchill's comments regarding 9/11 would shift the focus away from the intended subject of the conference.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. The director of center of law and policy said: "We felt that we had developed a very good and scholarly conference, and we wanted to proceed with it and that the best thing would be to not have his part of the keynote lunch."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

Students, faculty and legislators opposed  the UW-Whitewater Native American Support Services and the Native American Cultural Awareness Association ivitation to Churchill to speak on campus from because of Churchill's comments about 9/11 victims. Churchill delivered his speech.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university's chancellor said: "It is still my belief that the academy is at its best when it functions as a place for the free exchange of ideas . . . I do not share the fear of words apparently becoming more prevalent in our society."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society declared McAleese an "inappropriate speaker" for commencement and urged the university to rescind its invitation of McAleese because of McAleese's support for female ordination and gay rights. McAleese spoke successfully.

Hecklers disrupted the performance of the play, The Passion of the Musical, several times, accusing the playwright of racism. The hecklers' tickets were paid for by the school administration, who also organized the protest against the performance by encouraging students to stand up and say, “I'm offended,” whenever they felt that way during the performance.
Students protested Buchanan's conservative views on immigration. One student protester doused Buchanan in salad dressing during his speech, causing Buchanan to end the event early.
Public Response: Neutral. A university spokesperson said: “He [the protestor] could have faced a felony assault charge, but Pat Buchanan decided to not press that charge.”

Controversy Explanation: Wheaton College officials canceled a speaking event featuring Churchill, purportedly due to safety concerns, after learning of Churchill's comments about 9/11 victims.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous).  A spokesperson said: "It is important to have a free and open, civil and tolerant exchange of ideas take place in a safe environment.”

Controversy Explanation: After inviting Malkin to campus, the College Republicans disinvited her out of concern over her support for WWII internment policies. There is some indication by Malkin that the university administration may have threatened the student group's funding if it didn't revoke the invitation.

The Cardinal Newman Society took out a full-page ad in USA Today that said the president of the university — and the presidents of other mostly Catholic colleges and universities — was “permitting an obscenities-drenched production that defiles students” by allowing students to perform the play, The Vagina Monologues. The ad encouraged readers to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents on a provided list, which included their names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society declared Dellinger an "inappropriate speaker" for commencement because of his views on abortion and called on the law school to rescind Dellinger's invitation. Dellinger spoke successfully.

The university president claimed that Moore's campaigning for Democratic candidates disqualified him from speaking on college campuses during an election year and revoked Moore's invitation to speak because there was too little time to provide a "balancing perspective."
Public Response: Mistaken on the Law.  The director of communications said: “California law prohibits us from using state dollars for partisan political activity.”

A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

The managers of the university bookstore canceled Norton's speaking event in response to student demands that Norton be disinvited. The students objected to Norton's pro-choice views. University officials denied any responsibility for the disinvitation.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The university's director of public affairs stated: “since it was Follett's [the independent book store's] decision to book Ms. Norton, it was their decision [to revoke the invitation]”

The college then reinvited Gonzalez to speak at commencement but did not offer Gonzalez an honorary degree. Gonzales spoke successfully.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. The university president called Gonzales "a shining example of compassion and social justice" in the commencement speaker / honorary degree announcements, but then after protests, he rescinded the offer to award an honorary degree but still allowed Gonzales to come speak at a later date.

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society took out a full-page ad in USA Today that said the president of the university — and the presidents of other mostly Catholic colleges and universities — was “permitting an obscenities-drenched production that defiles students” by allowing students to perform the play, The Vagina Monologues. The ad encouraged readers to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents on a provided list, which included their names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society declared Prejean an "inappropriate speaker" for commencement because of her views on the death penalty and for writing the book, Dead Man Walking. The group called on the university to rescind Prejean's invitation. Prejean spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society took out a full-page ad in USA Today that said the president of the university — and the presidents of other mostly Catholic colleges and universities — was “permitting an obscenities-drenched production that defiles students” by allowing students to perform the play, The Vagina Monologues. The ad encouraged readers to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents on a provided list, which included their names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. The event took place.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The college's administration said that “much of the content and the language of The Vagina Monologues . . . is at odds with the ideals and values embodied in the Catholic tradition.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society took out a full-page ad in USA Today that said the president of the university — and the presidents of other mostly Catholic colleges and universities — was “permitting an obscenities-drenched production that defiles students” by allowing students to perform the play, The Vagina Monologues. The ad encouraged readers to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents on a provided list, which included their names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society took out a full-page ad in USA Today that said the president of Saint Ambrose College — and the presidents of other mostly Catholic colleges and universities — was “permitting an obscenities-drenched production that defiles students” by allowing students to perform the play, The Vagina Monologues. The ad encouraged parents and alumni to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents listed in the ad, which included the presidents' names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. College administrators refused to grant students permission to proceed with production of the play.

The ad encouraged readers to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents on a provided list, which included their names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. The event took place.

The event took place.

The ad encouraged readers to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents on a provided list, which included their names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. Students threw pies at Coulter in an attempt to shut down her speech, objecting to Coulter's views on religion and the war in Iraq. Coulter finished her talk despite the pie-throwing.
Small groups of students heckled Moore during his speech supporting John Kerry in the then-upcoming election. Moore completed his remarks but security ushered several groups out of the stadium.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university's speakers board director said: "ASUA is not passing judgment. We believe he has a unique way of presenting his ideas and addressing the opposition."

Controversy Explanation: Students heckled Pipes and attempted to shut down the event, objecting to Pipes' criticism of Islam. Pipes spoke despite the heckling.

During Yiannopoulos' talk, about 10 people got up and stood in front of the stage, chanting, "Two, four, six, eight — stop the violence, stop the rape." Other audience members then began chanting, "Trump! Trump! Trump!" About halfway through the speech, a student stood up and yelled that Yiannopoulos is a Nazi. Police escorted almost 20 protesters out of the event. Yiannopoulos finished his talk.

A student wrote an op-ed in the student paper calling for the College Republicans to disinvite Horowitz. Before the event, the student was joined by about a dozen protesters who argued that Horowitz is anti-Muslim and anti-black and that such "hate speech" should not be allowed. There were no disruptions at the event and Horowitz spoke successfully.

Student groups protested Glick's lecture, funded by the CEO of Davidsohn Gloabal Technologies, because of Glick's pro-Israel views. Student organizers canceled the event because of fears that it would alienate anti-Zionist students.

Students and community members petitioned the university to rescind Yiannopoulos' invitation, referring to him as a "bigot" and a "misogynist." Yiannopoulos spoke successfully, but protests occurred outside the event and one argument between protesters resulted in one of them being shot by the other.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. The university president released a statement explaining that, "while canceling this event would have meant canceling a speech by someone whose views I personally find repulsive, the next time it could be a speaker whose views are more in line with mine, but anathema to someone else."

Controversy Explanation: Protesters heckled and interrupted Shapiro throughout his speech. At one point, protesters formed a line in front of the stage and chanted before leaving on their own. Shapiro finished his remarks.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. In an official statement after Shapiro's speech, the university said: "We are dedicated to promoting a campus environment where all people feel valued and respected. To that end, the university expects community members to engage in discussion, especially over controversial issues, in ways that are respectful of others’ viewpoints and that promote greater understanding. We are disappointed that some attendees at the event chose not to do so."

Controversy Explanation: A student group, the Coalition Against the Ultra Right, and students petitioned the university to cancel Yiannopoulos' speech because of allegations that Yiannopolous promotes rape culture. A faculty group, UWM Against Hate, also petitioned to have Yiannopoulos disinvited. Yiannopoulos's invitation was not rescinded and he spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral. The university chancellor released a statement that read: "As with any student organization-sponsored event, the University is prohibited by law from restricting access to its facilities based on the organization's viewpoint or the viewpoints of any invited guest or speaker. Thus, Yiannopoulos’ visit must be permitted so long as the sponsoring student organization follows established content-neutral policies and procedures. Supporting free speech is one of UWM’s core values, even when some of those ideas are disagreeable or controversial. That being said, UWM does not endorse Yiannopoulos’ views. Also, no tuition or segregated fee funds are being used to support the event.

Speaker/Performer/Title: French Trappers on The Red Cedar
Controversy Explanation: After students complained, the university's Chancellor and Diversity Leadership Team planned to move two historic murals, including French Trappers on The Red Cedar, from public display to storage because they “reinforce racial stereotypes” of Native Americans. After pressure from free speech activists, including a letter co-authored by FIRE, the university did not move the paintings to storage but did move them to a less visible location.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university chancellor told reporters: "There's a segment of Native American students, that when they look at the art, to them it symbolizes an era of their history where land and possessions were taken away from them, and they feel bad when they look at them."

Controversy Explanation: After students complained, the university's Chancellor and Diversity Leadership Team planned to move two historic murals, including Perrault’s Trading Fort, from public display to storage because they “reinforce racial stereotypes” of Native Americans. After pressure from free speech activists, including a letter co-authored by FIRE, the university did not move the paintings to storage but did move them to a less visible location.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university chancellor told reporters: "There's a segment of Native American students, that when they look at the art, to them it symbolizes an era of their history where land and possessions were taken away from them, and they feel bad when they look at them. . . . [W]e want to make sure that, really, what we decorate our hallways with and what we put in our hallways is consistent with our values to try to attract more Native Americans to the university.”

Controversy Explanation: Administrators canceled Yiannopoulos' appearance in response to widespread criticism from students and alumni because of Yiannopoulos' views on race and feminism. The College Republicans claimed it hadn't extended an invitation: It had posted on Eventbrite to gauge how much interest there would be if he were invited.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said that "the club did not follow proper protocol in organizing the appearance, when they failed to garner approval from staff advisers and the administrators in the Office of Student Life."

Controversy Explanation: Students, faculty, and local activists opposed the business school's invitation of Murray to give a lecture on capitalism and freedom, objecting to Murray's earlier work on race and intelligence. The university defended the invitation of Murray, but also denounced Murray's prior work. Murray spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The president of the university said: "Dr. Murray is well known for his controversial and largely discredited work linking measures of intelligence to heredity, and specifically to race and ethnicity — a flawed socioeconomic theory that has been used by some to justify fascism, racism and eugenics."

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Judiciary System, Political Views, Police, Race
Controversy Explanation: The head of the finance department rejected the university's Pamplin College of Business's invitation to Riley to deliver the BB&T Distinguished Lecture because he and members of other departments feared a repeat of the "Charles Murray" protests because Riley had written on "race issues." Riley's talk was canceled. Riley was reinvited and he spoke on campus a year later.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The university president made a statement on Twitter: "As you may have heard, a faculty committee charged with making a recommendation for a Fall 2016 speaker made selection . . . and that invitation was accepted. We learned subsequently that a faculty member, without the knowledge of the committee . . . had extended an invitation to speak in that same slot to Jason Riley. . . . We regret the confusion and assure our friends, parents, students, alumni and partners that we will take the action necessary to ensure that such miscommunication does not occur in the future.”

Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the administration to cancel Yiannopoulos' appearance, alleging bigotry and "hate speech." They also organized an alternative event. The College Republicans canceled Yiannopolous' appearance due to adverse weather conditions, which forced the closure of an interstate highway.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university president stated: "Universities are free-speech areas, and whether I agree or disagree with his comments, he needs to have the ability to come on campus and articulate his particular views.”

Controversy Explanation: The administration resisted student calls to disinvite Yiannopoulos and he spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Neutral.  The university president defended Yiannopoulos before the event: "I will always support the decision to bring a speaker to campus and our community -- no matter how controversial. We never want to censor a person’s right to free speech. It is through listening to people who think differently from others that we learn about the world and discover who we really are. And I believe that is one of the most valuable experiences one can have on a college campus." 

But after the event the university president also Condemned the Speaker (or Artist) as Person (Not Views): He defended the reputation of a faculty member against what he saw as dishonest accusations by Yiannopoulos. The university president said: "It is one thing to share differing opinions that others may find offensive. It is another to be defamatory and target individuals. I personally condemn the tactic this speaker chose to vindictively attack one of our faculty members, Daniel Brewster."

Controversy Explanation: Derbyshire was invited to speak as part of the college's "Uncomfortable Learning" series in which some alumni pay for a student group to bring to campus speakers whose views might not otherwise be heard. The college president disinvited Derbyshire, calling Derbyshire's writing "hate speech."
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. A message from the college president's office included: "The college didn't invite Derbyshire, but I have made it clear to the students who did that the college will not provide a platform for him. . . . Many of his expressions clearly constitute hate speech, and we will not promote such speech on this campus or in our community."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Gayle because of Gayle's views on abortion. Gayle spoke successfully.

The student group Strong Americans at Yale indefinitely postponed Yiannopoulos' appearance after opposing Yiannopoulos tweeting that he would appear in a Native American costume and talk about cultural appropriation.

Students and faculty opposed Slaughter's selection as commencement speaker because of her scholarship and views on women's career success and because she is not a minority woman. A student started a petition urging the university to replace Slaughter with Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie. Slaughter spoke successfully.

Members of the campus chapter of Students for Justice in Palestine disuprted the film screening by shouting obscenities, blocking some students from entering the room where the film was being shown, and trying to push open the door to take the shouting inside the room. Police had to escort the students in the room to watch the film out and the screening was canceled.
Public Response: Honor Roll, High Honors, Neutral: The university chancellor said: "Last night, an incident occurred on campus that we believe crossed the line of civility, prompting me to re-emphasize our position on free speech, safety and mutual respect. The incident centered on a film-viewing event sponsored by Students Supporting Israel. A group of protesters reportedly disrupted the event, blocking exit paths. Participants feared for their safety, calling on our police force for assistance. While this university will protect freedom of speech, that right is not absolute. As I mentioned in a campus message at the beginning of the academic year, threats, harassment, incitement and defamatory speech are not protected. We must shelter everyone's right to speak freely -- without fear or intimidation -- and allow events to proceed without disruption and potential danger."

Controversy Explanation: The campus chapter of Young Americans for Freedom partnered with Fox News and the Michigan Review to host a screening of a Republican Presidential Primary Debate. Protesters attempted to disrupt the event repeatedly shouting “Donald Trump is racist!” and loudly beating a drum. A brief physical altercation occurred, but the event resumed and was completed successfully.

The SLU Young Republicans and Young America's Foundation invited West to campuus. Before the event, West wrote a blog post titled "Folks, I've just been CENSORED" claiming that a university administrator had told the SLU Young Republicans that they could not use the phrase "radical Islam" on their flyers promoting the event. In the blog post West also refered to the students as "little cupcakes" and said that the Muslim Student Association was a "stealth jihad radical Islamic campus organization." A group of law students wrote to the university administration and asked that the event be moved off-campus because the previous Fall SLU's Law Students for Reproductive Justice wanted to invite an attorney for Planned Parenthood, and former law professor, to speak but had their request rejected because the speech conflicted with the university's values. West spoke successfully, although some students silently walked out of the room as he delivered his speech.
Public Response: Neutral: “In recent days, many others and I have worked to hear and understand the pain our Muslim students and allies are feeling. Let me take this opportunity to remind these — and all — SLU students that I am in solidarity with you. As an institution of higher learning, SLU must resist the urge to suppress speech and instead expose all ideas and positions, provocative or pedestrian, to critical scrutiny. The fundamental purpose of a community of scholars and learners is to engage respectfully rather than repress.”

Controversy Explanation: Trump decided to cancel a rally on-campus due to safety concerns. A spokesperson for the campaign said that the decision was made after Mr. Trump met with law enforcment. A spokesperson for the Chicago Police Department denies this meeting took place and that they assured the Trump campaign "they had more than adequate resources and could guarantee him safe access and exit from the event, as well as the safety of all the attendees, supporters and protesters."
Public Response: Neutral.  The university police chief said: "The University of Illinois at Chicago worked with all appropriate agencies to address the security concerns associated with an event of this nature including the Secret Service, Chicago Police Department and Illinois State Police as well as campaign and protest organizers. The vast majority of attendees at today's events exercised their Constitutional rights of free speech and free assembly peacefully. The abrupt announcement of the cancellation of the event created challenges in managing an orderly exit from the Pavilion, which nonetheless, was accomplished with no injuries or arrests."

Controversy Explanation: The university's Committee on Art in Public Spaces decided to have a "hostile" stone carving of a Native American, armed with a bow, and a Puritan, armed with a musket, side by side outside the Sterling Memorial Library altered by covering the Puritan's musket in stone, that could be removed without damaging the original carving.

A university staff member smashed a stain glass window in Calhoun Hall twice with a broomstick because it depicted “slaves carrying bales of cotton." A woman walking by on the street outside was hit by some of the broken glass.
Public Response: Neutral.  In a statement to the local newspaper the university's vice president of communications said: "An incident occurred at Calhoun College, a residential college on the campus of Yale University, in which a stained glass window was broken by an employee of Yale, resulting in glass falling onto the street and onto a passerby, endangering [her] safety. The employee apologized for his actions and subsequently resigned from the University.  The University will not advocate that the employee be prosecuted in connection with this incident and is not seeking restitution."

Controversy Explanation: In 2014, after student and faculty complaints and a now discredited story about a gang rape at one of the university's frat houses was published in Rollong Stone, the university fromed a committee to consider what to do about The Student's Progress, a mural in a bulding on campus because some portions of it had been criticized for being sexist and mysoginist. About a year and. half later, in 2016, a faculty member at the university questioned why no decision had been made about altering, covering up, or moving a portion of the mural that depicts a professor and a student who "obviously have been doing something that would be a Title IX violation."

At the university's annual "Paint the Bridge" event, the campus chapter of the College Republicans included the phrase "Build the Wall" on their designated section of the mural. Later that evening a local non-profit group, NAVIAGTE MN, that supports undocumented students posted a picture of the mural. The next day at least 150 immigration activists protested the mural. The mural was tagged with graffiti multiple times throughout the semester.
Public Response: Honors.  In a statement the university's president said: "The University of Minnesota supports a campus climate that welcomes all members of our community and our values of equity and diversity, but that also ensures the free flow of ideas, even those that are offensive to some. People in our community may disagree with the sentiment expressed. However, while the University values free speech, the subsequent vandalism of the panel is not the way to advance a conversation."

Controversy Topic(s): Health, Political Views, Race, Civil Liberties, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Faculty members protested Carson's invitation because of his views on the Ferguson shooting, gay marriage, Obamacare, and other political issues. Carson spoke successfully.
A group of Baptist pastors protested the invitation of Flunder because she is a lesbian bishop. The college refused to disinvite Flunder.
Public Response: Supported Content of Expression. The college's president reacted by stating that to disinvite Flunder would "fly in the face of everything that A.B.C. stands for as an institution of higher education rooted in the cause of social justice and equality for all."

Controversy Explanation: College administrators disinvited former school psychologist Dr. Johnson from a campus Black History Month event after a group of students and a professor protested the invitation of Johnson, calling his rhetoric "anti-gay."
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. A college spokeswoman said that the administration decided that having Johnson speak on campus would not "foster the kind of academic discourse valued at AACC."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the college to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

The playwright contacted the university and asked it to recast multiple characters because he did not support the casting of Caucasians as Asian characters in his play. The university offered him the opportunity to make an on-stage speech and offered to devote a page in the playbill to his concerns, but argued that there wasn't enough time to replace the actors, particularly when less than 0.7 of 1 percent of the student population is Asian, less than a week before the performance. The playwright revoked the university's right to stage the production and it was canceled.

School: College of Our Lady of the Elms
Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Lewis to deliver a commencement speech because of Lewis' views on abortion, contraception, and stem-cell research. Lewis spoke successfuly.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the college to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

The Israel Project, an off-campus group, claimed Chomsky is a virulent and unfair critic of Israel and petitioned the university to rescind Chomsky's invitation to speak at commencement and his honorary degree. The university refused and Chomsky spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The university director of media relations made a statement, including “The awarding of honorary degrees does not in any way indicate endorsement of a recipient’s opinions. . . . As a scientist, Chomsky’s work is at the forefront of his discipline, and he is often described as the ‘father of modern linguistics.’"

Controversy Explanation: Muslim students characterized Nomani's views as Islamophobic. Duke canceled the event, then called its cancellation a "misunderstanding." Nomani spoke on campus.

During the first of two screenings of the film, American Sniper, about 40 protesters went on stage with signs to protest the screening. Campus police temporarily detained four protesters. After the delay, the film was shown in its entirety, but the second screening was rescheduled.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship, Appeased Protesters. A university spokesperson said: "Eastern Michigan University is an open and diverse community, with many perspectives and viewpoints. The University respects the rights of its students to speak out on issues of importance to them, and encourages civil debate and discussion that promotes empathy and understanding."

Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the university to cancel a screening of the film, American Sniper. The university refused to cancel the screening and the event proceeded as planned.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

Police objected to the Women’s Law Association and the Law and International Development Society's invitation of Steinberg, the head of "Bronx Defenders" who was accused of taking part in a video endorsing killing cops after Eric Garner's death. The student groups that invited Steinberg rescinded their invitation but said they would invite her again if the accusations proved to be false. Several other student groups started a petition arguing that disinviting Steinberg was wrong, and they began planning to invite her to an event themselves.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Hochul to deliver a commencement speech because of Hochul's views on abortion. Hochul spoke successfuly.

Police groups protested the university's invitation of Common to deliver a commencement speech because of a song in which Common portrayed as a victim a woman convicted of killing a police officer. The university rescinded its invitation.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. The VP for university relations said that the announcement had been "released prematurely . . . [after] students expressed interest in Common because he composed the Oscar-winning song ‘Glory’. . . . While we respect Common’s talent, Kean is pursuing other speaker options.”

Controversy Explanation: Students and faculty asked the college to remove Archbishop Dolan as a commencement speaker because of handling of allegations of sexual abuse within the Catholic church and his comments about homosexuality. Dolan spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. A college spokesperson said: "Cardinal Dolan is arguably the most influential leader within the U.S. Catholic Church, and we're confident his message will be compelling and impact a wide range of people in the audience."  

Appeased Protesters. BUT the president of the college said: "In reality I see it as a great call for celebration. Our students are questioning decisions we've made. They want to understand the rationale at a deeper level. They're indicating concern for members of society that are historically marginalized. I think Cardinal Dolan will take some joy in the fact that our students are well educated and want more questions answered. It's a sign of engagement."

Controversy Explanation: The university president revoked Merritt's invitation to give an alumni lecture because of Merritt's writing criticizing Hobby Lobby and Jerry Falwell, the president's father.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. Merritt wrote in a column what the university president told him: "'We're just uncomfortable with some of the things you've been writing."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Tagliabue to deliver a commencement speech because of Tagliabue's support for gay marriage. Tagliabue spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.
Project:Theatre, a student group, canceled the annual performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, because it excludes the experiences of transgender women.
Public Response: Encouraged (Approved of) Self-Censorship. A college spokesperson said: "The student-group decision to cancel the play was made independently of the College's transgender admission policy. As a women's college with a long tradition of educating women leaders, Mount Holyoke College supports and encourages students to take the lead in establishing and governing their own organizations. The College encourages students to seek peer input through open discussion and to consider and respect all viewpoints in their decision-making process."

Controversy Explanation: Student protesters called Sommers a "rape denialist" and declared her brand of feminism dangerous and unsafe. Activists created separate "safe spaces." Others heckled Sommers during the speech, which she completed successfully.

A faculty member overseeing the production of a student-created performance called "The Politics of Dancing," which included an exploration of transgender and other gender issues, met with the head of the theater department and was told that the theater class producing the play would have to change direction or perform elsewhere. The performance did not occur.

The university president disinvited Bell, an Adventist pastor-turned-humanist, from giving a lecture because Bell's religious views diverged from those of the Adventist church. Administrators encouraged anyone in possession of school yearbooks from the time period Bell attended the college to throw them on a Halloween bonfire.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. The president wrote Bell he was disinvited "to keep the institution true to its mission as a Seventh-day Adventist institution of higher learning owned and maintained by the Adventist Church."

Controversy Topic(s): Criminal or Other Misconduct, Political Views, Terrorism
Controversy Explanation: Ayers' past militant activity led students and a state legislator to request that the university cancel the event. The university declined to cancel the event and Ayers spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The law school's communications director told the press: “Anytime you bring in someone with a viewpoint, you are going to have someone disagree with that viewpoint. We're trying to foster a diverse marketplace of ideas.” A different spokesperson said: “They [the students] are free to sponsor programs and speakers — however controversial — without censorship by the university. . . . Of course, the presence of any speaker cannot be taken as an endorsement by the university of his/her views.”

Controversy Explanation: Students opposed Bar-Yoshafat (and Ranya Fadel) for his pro-Israel views, and hecklers shut the speech down. Sponsoring students claimed administrators and campus police did little to stop the disruptions: They asked one heckler to leave, otherwise they just held back the crowds and escorted the speakers out.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said that security officers followed the university’s “usual approach to conflict, which is to resolve issues with dialogue and engagement wherever possible."

Controversy Explanation: Students opposed Radel (and Ran Bar-Yoshafat) for her pro-Israel views, and hecklers shut the speech down. Sponsoring students claimed administrators and campus police did little to stop the disruptions: They asked one heckler to leave, then held back the crowds and escorted the speakers out.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said that security officers followed the university’s “usual approach to conflict, which is to resolve issues with dialogue and engagement wherever possible."

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Criminal or Other Misconduct, Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
Controversy Explanation: The organizer of the TEDxUC Irvine conference disinvited Shabaik from speaking at the conference, citing Shabaik's "overtly political" nature and his past as a member of the "Irvine 11," who disrupted a 2010 event featuring Israeli Ambassador Michael Oren.
Public Response: Encouraged (Approved of) Self-Censorship. Student organizers said in response to pressure from the administration: Shabaik’s speech was "not in line" with what a TED talk was "supposed" to be.

Controversy Explanation: The local Congregation B'nai Israel and it's rabbi opposed Darwish's invitation to campus. As the event began, a group of students "mic checked," yelling that Darwish speaks for Israeli apartheid. Physical altercations between the students and other audience members ensued. No arrests were made.

School: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill
Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Civil Liberties, Race
Controversy Explanation: Students opposed Bloomberg because of his treatment of the Occupy Wall Street movement and his support of NYPD's "stop-and-frisk" policy, and they circulated a petition online demanding Bloomberg's invitation to speak at commencement be rescinded. Students organized an alternative commencement ceremony. Bloomberg spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person.  The university announced Bloomberg as speaking because of his "extraordinary career in business, philanthropy, and public service."

Controversy Explanation: The university canceled Miller's performance art workshop after Catholic bloggers and commentators objected to Miller's gay rights activism.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The official university statement included: "We had concerns that his performances were not in keeping with our Catholic and Augustinian values and mission."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded Boston College cancel an event posthumously honoring Fr. Robert Drinan because of Drinan's views on abortion and because the speakers chosen — Frank (and Raymond Schroth) — were pro-choice. They also objected to Frank's homosexuality. Frank spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college cancel an event posthumously honoring Fr. Robert Drinan because of Drinan's views on abortion and because the speakers chosen — Schroth (and Barney Frank) — were pro-choice. They also objected to Frank's homosexuality. Schroth spoke successfully.

School: City University of New York, John Jay
Controversy Explanation: Kushner faced opposition from university board members  because of his views on Israel, and the university's board of trustees voted to deny him an honorary degree. The board later reversed this decision and Kushner accepted the degree.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The chair of board of trustees wrote in a public statement: "I would not ordinarily ask for reconsideration of a decision so recently taken, but when the board has made a mistake of principle, and not merely of policy, review is appropriate and, indeed, mandatory. . . . Like other honorary degrees, It is not intended to reflect approval or disapproval for political views not relevant to the field for which the recipient is being honored. Any other view is impractical as well as wrong in principle."

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Environment, Political Views, Race
Controversy Explanation: 75 faculty members signed a letter protesting the college's decision to award Bush an honorary degree without their input. They also criticized Bush's conservative policies. Bush was awarded the degree and spoke at commencement.
The college faced outside pressure to disinvite Ibrahim because of his comments reagrding Islam. Ibrahim spoke successfully.

Students and faculty protested the university's invitation of Mortenson to deliver a commencement speech after Mortenson was accused of being inaccurate in his book. The university rescinded its invitation to Mortenson.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. The university president said: "The purpose of our commencement is to honor Fontbonne graduates. . . . We want to focus on their achievements and accomplishments."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and provided a sample letter on its website that included the contact information of the university's president. Student Affairs did not approve the performance, so the student organizers held it off campus instead.

A faculty member contributed a painting to the Faculty Biennial Exhibition depicting torch-wielding Ku Klux Klan members and a lynching superimposed onto an image of the Confederate flag. Following public criticism of the painting, the university president removed it without notifying the faculty member or the art gallery director.
Public Response:
Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. In multiple statements the college president said: "First and foremost, I have to consider the impact of an action on the health and reputation of the institution. In this instance, I made a judgment call that the negative results would outweigh the positive ones."

"I stand behind my original decision which was not based on any one group’s agenda, complaint, or the overall content of the painting. It focused solely on the image that has been perceived as  aggressively hostile in other areas of the country and other academic institutions—that being the graphic depiction of a lynching."

Controversy Topic(s): Environment, Foreign Affairs, Political Views, Race, Religion

Students also created a Facebook page opposing the invitation. Coulter spoke successfully with little interruption.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The Lecture Fund VP said: "We promote free exchange, and we are nonpartisan and that is extremely important to us.”

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

The university president revoke Gannon's invitation by the sign-language studies department to teach a workshop on sexual issues amid protests by on-campus and off-campus groups over Gannon's pro-choice views. An online brochure advertising the event was also removed from the university website.

The university president informed students by email: "I wanted to inform you as soon as possible that there will be no speaker from Planned Parenthood at Madonna University (including the Orchard Lake or any other MU extension). You can share this with our Campus Ministry students. I am sure this will bring relief to their parents as well. Thank you for your prayers."

Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The college dean stated: “In order to educate students who can thoughtfully engaged and serve the church and society, students must encounter many different points of view, and they must be guided and nurtured as they reflect on, assess and apply those points of view.”

Controversy Explanation: The College Republicans, who invited Matera to campus to provide a response to Frances Piven's lecture, rescinded the invitation after learning Matera made "inappropriate" comments at another college.
The university rescinded its invitation to Fox due to Fox's support for drug legalization. Another area school invited Fox to speak after the cancellation.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression.  A university spokesperson explained: “Point Loma Nazarene University considered hosting an event on campus featuring former president of Mexico Vicente Fox. However, we decided not to host the event. . . .While Fox’s stance on drug legalization did factor into our eventual decision to not host this event, it was not the sole deciding factor.”

Controversy Explanation: The college banned performances of the play, The Vagina Monologues, on campus in 2006 because "its depiction of female sexuality is so deeply at odds with the true meaning and morality that the Catholic Church’s teaching celebrates." Students performed the play off campus for the fifth year straight.
Students wanted to prevent District Attorney Dumanis from speaking because her office had not prosecuted a suspect in a murder case. Dumanis canceled the appearance.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to revoke its speaking invitation to Brown because of Brown's views on abortion. The college disinvited Brown.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. A news article reported: “The Globalization Program has canceled the lecture . . . . Some previous statements made by the planned speaker were contrary to the spirit and mission of Siena College.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society objected to Goodman's appearance due to her pro-choice views. The college administration revoked Goodman's invitation.

The student finance board initially denied security funding for a College Republican-run event featuring Horowitz, objecting to Horowitz's views on race and Islam. The university administration stepped in and allocated $800 for security. Horowitz spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

Hundreds of students, including almost 100 of the university's graduating class, emailed school officials opposing the law school's invitation of Portman to deliver a commencement speech. Portman spoke successfully.

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Political Views
Controversy Explanation: Students urged the university not to choose Snyder as a commencement speaker due to Snyder's proposed higher education budget cuts and other conservative policies. Snyder spoke successfully while protests occurred outside, and some students turned their backs to him during his speech.
Public Response: Neutral. The university president said: “We are pleased that Governor Rick Snyder has accepted our invitation to be the commencement speaker and address our graduates. . . . His appearance continues a U of M tradition of inviting the newly elected governor to be the graduation speaker. Governors Milliken, Blanchard, Engler and Granholm all have addressed graduating classes, and Governor Snyder will extend this tradition.”

Controversy Explanation: Students and off-campus groups including Occupy Philadelphia and labor unions gathered on campus to protest Cantor's economic policies, leading him to withdraw from speaking just hours before his speech.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

After an off-campus press conference was disrupted earlier in the day, the university moved Clegg's debate with law professor Larry Church from the law school to a larger university hall and provided additional security for the event. Clegg was hissed and booed throughout his talk, but was able to speak successfully.

More than a hundred students disrupted Clegg's morning press conference at a local hotel becasue they objected to findings from two studies conducted by Clegg's organization, the Center for Equal Opportunity. Clegg was forced to shut the press conference down.

Students for Life and the Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Casey Jr. because Casey Jr. is pro-contraception and, in the groups' view, not strong enough in his anti-abortion stance. Casey Jr. spoke successfully.

Students protested and started a referendum to repeal the university's funding for Palin to speak at a sexual responsibility event. Some students objected to Palin's pro-abstinence position, but others objected to spending student funds on having a political figure tell her personal story rather than having an expert speak. Palin and the Student Health Advisory Committee, which had invited her, mutually agreed she shouldn't speak.
Public Response: Neutral. The president of the University Student Health Advisory Committee responded to protestors with: "We're not asking you to agree with what Bristol [Palin] says."

Controversy Explanation: Universal Beatz and multiple student organizations that invited Casey, an Israeli "cultural ambassador," to perform at an international hip-hop event revoked its invitation after facing pressure from on-campus and off-campus members of the pro-Palestinian Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions movement.

Students tried to get the university to uninvite Tillerson because of Tillerson's relationship with Exxon. When the administration refused to disinvite Tillerson, students organized a separate commencement address.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The university president's statement included: "Rex Tillerson is one of this nation’s most successful business leaders, a recognized and respected authority on energy, a champion of science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) education, and a friend to WPI."

Controversy Explanation: Students opposed the university's selection of Oren to deliver a commencement speech, including by starting a facebook page protesting the selection, objecting to Oren's pro-Israel views. Oren spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The university president said: “Each of these distinguished individuals, in his or her own way, represents the pillars of this university and its mission. Awarding these honorary degrees is the last lesson we pass along to our students before they leave."

Controversy Explanation: Faculty rejected a student proposal to invite Roberts, the chief justice of the U.S. Supreme Court, because they like to avoid inviting political figures to be commencement speakers.

Students protested Palin, objecting to her conservative politics and the school's refusal to disclose Palin's speaking fee when Palin was invited to speak at the university's 50th anniversary gala hosted by the CSU Stanislaus Foundation. This prompted local activists to call to rescind Palin's invitation, and when students found part of Palin's contract in the trash the state attorney general placed the university's foundation arm under investigation. Palin spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral. The president of the foundation board stated: "Friday’s sold-out dinner was expected to bring in more than $200,000, which would make the gala the most successful fundraiser in the university’s history . . . We're not here to make a political statement, we're here to make money."

School: Columbia University School of International and Public Affairs
Controversy Explanation: Students protested Pandit's career as a bank executive and created a Facebook group called, "We don't want a bank executive to speak at our commencement." Pandit spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Content of Expression. The dean wrote: "He [Pandit] is unusually thoughtful and forthright on the role of Citi and other banks leading up to the crisis, most recently in testifying before Congressional committees. . . . I think that students and their families will find Mr. Pandit, who favors better regulation of the banking industry, to be an unusually interesting graduation speaker."

Controversy Explanation: The university originally banned performances of The Vagina Monologues in 2002, stating that it is "vulgar," describes lesbian activity in a positive manner, and reduces “sexuality to selfish pleasure.” The interim president upheld the ban, preventing the performance, and students protested.

The university claimed Woods "lacked sufficient academic credibility" and twice denied funding to the Young Americans for Libery for an event featuring Woods. The students independently raised money to bring Woods to campus, the administration ultimately partially funded the event, and Woods spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as Person (Not Views). The university's statement said that Woods was "Uncredentialed."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Patrick to deliver a commencement speech because of Patrick's views on abortion and his support for gay marriage. Patrick spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Carter because of Carter's views on abortion and her support for gay marriage. Carter spoke successfully.
The university banned performances of the play, The Vagina Monologues, on campus in 2006. Students performed the play off campus for the third year straight.

The Cardinal Newman Society took out a full-page ad in USA Today that said the president of the university — and the presidents of other mostly Catholic colleges and universities — was “permitting an obscenities-drenched production that defiles students” by allowing students to perform the play, The Vagina Monologues. The ad encouraged readers to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents on a provided list, which included their names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. The event took place.
Public Response: Neutral. The assistant director of university communications responded to the ad saying: "The subject matter that is raised by the play is certainly a valid discussion to be raised in an academic environment, aside from the whole issue of artistic performance."
