Students protested the student government's invitation of rapper Big Sean to perform at commencement and asked that the invitation be rescinded, alleging that Big Sean promotes rape culture. The student government did not rescind the invitation, and some students held an alternate event.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as a Person, Appeased Protesters. The university president referred to Urban Congo as "offensive" and to Big Sean’s lyrics as "vile and demeaning.”

Controversy Explanation: Senior college officials postponed a screening of the film, American Sniper, after students complained. The screening was rescheduled for the next week and was coupled with an educational forum that would allow students to "participate in an intellectual discourse about the film and current world events."
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship, Appeased Protesters. The college's Vice President for Strategic Communications said: "[T]his decision [to postpone the showing] was made solely by members of the UPAC Cinema Club, after careful consideration of a request by the RPI Muslim Students Association. . . . UPAC has decided that they will show American Sniper during this spring semester, at a date to be announced. The showing will be coupled with an optional educational forum for all members of the Rensselaer campus community to participate in an intellectual discourse about the film and current world events. . . .On behalf of President Shirley Ann Jackson and the Rensselaer administration, we applaud this decision, and this decision-making process. At its core, The New Polytechnic at Rensselaer is guided by societal concerns and ethics."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Mitchell to deliver a commencement speech because of Mitchell's views on abortion. Mitchell spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Nutter to deliver a commencement speech because of Nutter's support for gay marriage, contraception, and abortion. Nutter spoker successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance. The play was performed off campus.

School: Saint Louis University School of Law
Controversy Explanation: Members of the Black Law Students Association asked the school’s dean to rescind its invitation of McCulloch because of McCulloch's role as the prosecutor in the Ferguson police shooting case. McCulloch spoke successfully after police escorted approximately 12 disruptive protesters from the event.

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Matthews to deliver a commencement speech because of Matthews' views on abortion and gay rights. Matthews spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Brooks to deliver a commencement speech because of Brooks' support for gay marriage. Brooks spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.
Students petitioned the university to rescind Rauner's invitation to speak at commencement, objecting to Rauner's proposed budget cuts to the university system. Rauner spoke successfully.

Faculty members protested the college's selection of Giuliani to deliver a commencement address, calling Giuliani a "controversial, divisive ideologue" and objecting to Giuliani's comments regarding African American communities and crime. The college refused to disinvite Giuliani and he spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The college president said: "Mr. Giuliani is expected to speak about his role in the Sept. 11 recovery. I believe this will be of interest and value to our students."

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Civil Liberties, Gender, Political Views, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: hooks hosted a conversation with Gloria Steinem which became a subject of controversy. A local bishop called on the college to rescind its invitation to Steinem. TFP Student Action, an off-campus organization, petitioned the college to cancel Steinem's conversation with hooks because of Steinem's views on abortion, same-sex marriage, feminism, religion, and Marxism (many of which hooks shared). The petition garnered more than 28,000 signatures. hooks spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as Person (Not Views). "Throughout the week, the social-justice scholar hooks will host a number of talks related to her work on topics including the theology of love and radical hospitality, community building and racial inequality. She and Steinem will participate in a dialogue on April 21. We are not expecting Ms. hooks and Ms. Steinem to be discussing abortion. These two influential figures have conducted such a dialogue four or five times before, and abortion has seldom if ever come up. Rather, they will share their perspectives on the ways roles and opportunities for women have evolved in their lifetimes, and the impact changes have had on the country. Steinem also has spoken a great deal about domestic violence in recent years. Obviously we have a somewhat different view of the question of speakers on a college campus, but we respect the bishop's desire to comment on something he feels so strongly about."

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Civil Liberties, Gender, Political Views, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: A local bishop called on the college to rescind its invitation to Steinem and TFP Student action, an off-campus organization, started a petition demanding the college cancel Steinem's conversation with author Gloria Jean Watkins (pen name: bell hooks) because of Steinem's views on abortion, gay marriage, feminism, religion, and Marxism. The petition garnered more than 28,000 signatures, but Steinem spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as Person (Not Views). "Throughout the week, the social-justice scholar hooks will host a number of talks related to her work on topics including the theology of love and radical hospitality, community building and racial inequality. She and Steinem will participate in a dialogue on April 21. We are not expecting Ms. hooks and Ms. Steinem to be discussing abortion. These two influential figures have conducted such a dialogue four or five times before, and abortion has seldom if ever come up. Rather, they will share their perspectives on the ways roles and opportunities for women have evolved in their lifetimes, and the impact changes have had on the country. Steinem also has spoken a great deal about domestic violence in recent years. Obviously we have a somewhat different view of the question of speakers on a college campus, but we respect the bishop's desire to comment on something he feels so strongly about."

Controversy Explanation: Conservative students argued that university funds shouldn't be used to have Davis speak, claiming much of the student body doesn't respect Davis because of her leftist views. Davis spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as Person (Not Views). A VP for for Undergraduate Education and Student Affairs published a statement that included: “The caliber of speakers who will be part of our African-American Lecture Series further affirms our commitment to diversity and the profound contributions of African-Americans to our campus, state and country.”

Controversy Explanation: As part of an art project, a graduate student posted signs that said "White Only" and "Black Only" by water fountains and outside bathrooms on campus. Campus police removed the signs and administrators said they would "review this matter through appropriate university policies and procedures."
Public Response: Neutral (disingenuous). We are committed to ensuring that the University at Buffalo is welcoming and supportive of all members of our community. On a daily basis our faculty and students explore sensitive and difficult topics in an environment that values freedom of expression, and this week’s student art project is generating considerable dialogue. The university is encouraging our community to discuss how we negotiate the boundaries of academic freedom in a safe and inclusive environment that values freedom of expression and further builds a culture of inclusion. The University at Buffalo stands strong in our commitment to ensuring that such discourse occurs in a safe, inclusive and intellectually open environment."

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Race, Other
Controversy Explanation: Students chanted and shouted throughout a discussion between Provost Steele (and Chancellor Dirks) on the meaning and value of higher education. The students said that black students suffered hardships, that Dirks' salary was too high, and that the university did not grant tenure to a particular environmental science professor. The chanting and shouting briefly stopped when The Berkeley Forum, the event organizers, announced it would reformat the Q&A period to accommodate all audience members instead of only the handful who had been preselected to ask questions. The event was shut down when the chanting and shouting resumed after Steele (and Dirks) declined to comment on some of the questions.
Student groups denounced the Black Student Union's invitation of Farrakhan to campus and petitioned the university to rescind his invitation, but Farrakhan spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university president wrote in an open letter: "[W]e cannot as a society allow what we regard as vile speech to lead us to abandon the cherished value of free speech. . . [we should, however] condemn these merchants of hatred when they come into our community."

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Race, Other
Controversy Explanation: Students chanted and shouted throughout a discussion between Chancellor Dirks (and Provost Steele) on the meaning and value of higher education. The students said that black students suffered hardships, that Dirks' salary was too high, and that the university did not grant tenure to a particular environmental science professor. The chanting and shouting briefly stopped when The Berkeley Forum, the event organizers, announced they would reformat the Q&A period to accommodate all audience members instead of just the handful who had been preselected to ask questions. The event was shut down when the chanting and shouting resumed after Dirks (and Steele) declined to comment on some of the questions.

Some Jewish leaders on campus (and off campus) opposed UCLA’s Alan D. Leve Center for Jewish Studies' invitation of West due to his criticism of Israel and support for the BDS movement. The director of the center refused to rescind the invitation and West spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as Person (Not Views). The director of the center that invited West, held fast in a statement to reporters:  "[I don't] excuse, justify, or apologize for West’s positions on Israel . . . We may have pressure to rescind the invitation but that’s not the plan. . . . We didn't ask him [West] to come to UCLA to espouse a particular political position or platform—we asked him to talk about Heschel and the relationship to the civil rights movement.”

Controversy Explanation: The university president announced that the university would cover the mural because of its stereotypical depictions of black musicians and Native Americans. In 2016, the university uncovered the mural because it “told a story through a talented artist’s eyes within the context of her time.”

A petition called on student group organizers of a screening of the film, American Sniper, to cancel the screening, calling the film "war propaganda guised as art" and saying it "reveals a not-so-discreet Islamophobic, violent, and racist nationalist ideology." After meeting with students who opposed the screening, organizers postponed it, then met with other student groups to arrange a screening along with a discussion panel following the event. The screening took place two weeks later.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship, Appeased Protesters. The university president released a statement: SEE, the event organizer,  "is a student-run organization comprised of undergraduate students who work alongside advisers in the creation, promotion and operation of campus events. . . . The university is not involved in the decision-making process to determine which films are brought to campus. . . . I take tremendous pride in the conduct of our students. MSA members were right to speak up for what they believe in. They deserve our admiration, not the scorn and vitriol they got on Facebook. I also applaud the student leaders of SEE for listening to the concerns of their fellow students. Their decision to reschedule the screening so a constructive dialogue could be held marks the exercise of free speech and a sensitivity to campus values of respect and inclusion."

Controversy Explanation: Student groups and students petitioned the university to cancel the a screening of the film, American Sniper, because of its "negative and misleading stereotypes" of Muslims and because it "sympathizes with a mass killer." University administrators canceled the screening. After public outcry, the university rescheduled the event, and it proceeded without incident.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship, Appeased Protesters. The university president said: "Though I agree that the initial cancellation was a mistake due to free speech and choice issues it created, I am also very concerned for those who feel marginalized and hurt by certain types of speech. Muslim students on our campus have shared some of their experiences with me in this regard. As a community, we must confront all of these issues in order to provide a safe and free place to learn and interact, and an environment that is conducive to the discussion of controversial topics."

Controversy Explanation: During a speech by Halbertal on assymetrical warfare, students and off-campus groups shouted, making enough noise that Halbertal required about half an hour, and the removal of several protesters, to begin speaking. Protesters objected to Halbertal's views on war crimes and civilian casualties. After about 30 minutes, Halbertal resumed his lecture and completed his remarks.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The dean's official statement included: "As members of a university community, we should welcome -- indeed, insist -- on hearing a wide range of viewpoints, and we should condemn any efforts to silence free speech through protests of the sort that took place at the law school yesterday. . . . [It] is unacceptable that they [the protestors] should seek to deny other students and community members their own opportunity to hear an invited guest speak. Values of free speech and academic freedom are central to the University’s mission; we disregard them at our peril."

Controversy Explanation: Students wrote letters to the student government asking it to cancel a screening of the film, American Sniper, after a student wrote a letter to the editor of the student newspaper describing the movie as dehumanizing to Muslims and said the screening would make her feel unsafe. The screening proceeded as planned.

Students petitioned the university to disinvite Abbott from delivering a commencement speech because of Abbott's views on immigration and his opposition to same-sex marriage, claiming these views do "not align with the spirit of the University of North Texas." Abbott spoke at commencement after police removed a dozen protesters.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university president said: "I don't expect the whole campus to appreciate the points of view of [a speaker] or endorse them . . . But I expect them to listen because creating an informed and educated citizenry and engaging in public dialog and discourse is a healthy thing for our campus."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of then-President Obama to deliver a commencement speech because of Obama's views on abortion and his support for stem-cell research. An online petition created by the Cardinal Newman Society opposed the university's invitation of Obama and garnered almost 65,000 signatures. Obama spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral. A university spokesperson said: "I can't foresee that occurring [that the invitation be revoked]. We made an invitation to the president and he's accepted. We expected criticism and it's nothing beyond what we expected."

Controversy Explanation: After an activist organization criticized the film, Honor Diaries, as Islamophobic, the university canceled a screening of the film "because the format and setting did not allow for appropriate discussion following the screening." The university rescheduled the screening for later in the semester during a women's conference.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship, Appeased Protesters. In an email the university provost said: "The University of South Dakota supports free speech and robust discussion of controversial topics in a setting that offers respect to all involved. The earlier showing of ‘Honor Diaries’ was cancelled because the format and setting did not allow for appropriate discussion following the screening.  Whenever USD hosts speakers or films that are controversial the goal is to promote education and better understanding of the people and issues involved."

Controversy Explanation: Anti-amnesty activists shouted down Gutierrez's speech because of his views on immigration. Gutierrez left before the scheduled Q&A.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

Venker was invited to attend a student-run, alumni-funded speaking series titled the "Uncomfortable Learning" series. The students who run the series disinvited her because other students objected to her criticism of feminism and felt she used sexist and homophobic stereotypes. When reinvited, Venker declined the invitation.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. A spokesperson for the university made it clear that Venker was disinvited by the students who had asked her to speak in the first place, not by the college. "[Williams has] a history of bringing controversial speakers to campus. . . . We don't shy away from that.  [For example,] We don't cancel commencement speakers."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation to Johnson to deliver a commencement speech, calling Johnson "an outspoken advocate for HIV/AIDS prevention and safe sex." Johnson spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Holder to deliver a commencement speech because of Holder's support for the Affordable Care Act. Holder spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Landrieu to deliver a commencement speech because of Landrieu's views on abortion. Landrieu spoke successfully.

The Vice Dean of Harvard's law school, told Teng, a human rights lawyer and fellow at the Harvard Kennedy School, to cancel a discussion he had organized between himself and Chen Guangchen, a fellow Chinese dissident, because the discussion was scheduled a day after Harvard's presiedent was flying back from Beijing after meeting Xi Jingping and holding it would "embarass" Harvard. Teng canceled the event and was asked not to discuss it.
Public Response: Neutral: The Vice Dean of the law school said: "Having for years served on the Scholars at Risk Committee and for decades hosted a broad range of scholars and law related activists from China at HLS, I tried to make Dr. Teng’s time here academically fruitful. I invited him to speak in my class around the time in question, introduced him to colleagues and met with him frequently about his research, his plans, and his family. I did ask that he schedule the event in question after our University President had left Beijing."

Controversy Explanation: Chen was invited to participate in a discussion by Teng Biao, a fellow at the Harvard Kennedy School. Twice before the scheduled evenet, the Vice Dean of Harvard's law school contacted Teng and asked him to cancel the discussion, because it was scheduled a day after Harvard's presiedent was flying back from Beijing after meeting Xi Jingping and holding it would "embarass" Harvard. Teng canceled the event and was asked not to discuss it.
Public Response: Neutral: The Vice Dean of the law school said: "Having for years served on the Scholars at Risk Committee and for decades hosted a broad range of scholars and law related activists from China at HLS, I tried to make Dr. Teng’s time here academically fruitful. I invited him to speak in my class around the time in question, introduced him to colleagues and met with him frequently about his research, his plans, and his family. I did ask that he schedule the event in question after our University President had left Beijing."

Controversy Explanation: The campus chapter of Law Students for Reproductive Justice invited Raclin, the chair of the board of trustees for Planned Parenthood in St. Louis and a former professor at the university, to give a speech on campus. Shortly before the event the university pressured Law Students for Reporoductive Justice to move the event off-campus because Raclin's views on abortion raised  "issues of Catholic moral and ethical teaching." The event was moved off-campus.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous): The vice president of marketing and communications said: "Bob McCulloch speaking at the law school did not raise issues of Catholic moral and ethical teaching, whereas in this case, there's a potential conflict with Catholic teaching. That's the difference between the two."

Controversy Explanation: After a faculty member saw the Assata Shakur mural on the university's Gender and Sexuality Resource Center's Facebook page and criticized it because Shakur, formerly known as Joanne Chesimard, was on the FBI's list of most wanted terrorists for killing a state trooper in New Jersey, and then escaping prison and fleeing to Cuba, administrators decided to have a mural of Shakur painted over because "the mural does not reflect the Guiding Values of Marquette University."
Public Response: Condemned Expression.  In a statement the university said: "This is extremely disappointing as the mural does not reflect the Guiding Values of Marquette University. It is being removed immediately. We are reviewing the circumstances surrounding the mural and will take appropriate action."

Controversy Explanation: A university administrator informed the artist, Cory Oberndorfer, that he would either have to cover the word fucking on his mural or destroy it. Oberndorfer painted over the word with a black rectangle. University administrators later informed Oberndorfer that he could restore his mural to its original state as long as he would cover up the word upon request during special events.
Public Response: Disingenuous.  In an offical statement the university said: "American University will not censor art. The mural, “Bitter/Sweet” by Cory Oberndorfer, currently showing in the center will remain there. The center will work with Mr. Oberndorfer to restore the mural to its original state. However, we hope that the community appreciates our intention to be sensitive and responsible as we display art in a very public space. As much as our goal is to preserve and share the vision of artists, we must also consider the young students, children, parents, and all members of the community who grace our halls throughout the day."

Controversy Explanation: A staff member at the college temporarily blocked access to Essense of Self, an art exhibit featuring images of men and women engaging in homosexual actions with themselves, by posting a sign outide the exhibit that read: "WARNING: MATURE CONTENT ART SHOWING IN PROGRESS." The staff member also locked the doors, and covered the windows and doors to restrict visibility of the exhibit. A faculty member unlocked the door and removed the covers from the artwork.

After student and faculty complaints, the college president temporarily covered two murals, which depicts a meeting between English colonists and Mohawk tribal members before the 1755 Battle of Lake George, in The Log building on campus after it reopened. He then created a committee to provide a recommendation for how to address the concerns about the murals. A year later the committee recommended that the the college keep the mural but add descriptions contextualizing it. In 2019, the college hung a plaque next to the murals explaining that the mural's artist "“often included racially stereotyped images of Native people" in his artwork. In 2020, a new college president announced that the murals would be removed and "preserved as artifacts for scholarly study."
Public Response: Neutral.  In an email to the campus community the college president said: "The murals, found on the walls of the Log, attracted concern because of the artist’s portrayal of Native Americans and of the relationship between the Mohawks and the British. This fall we’ll relocate the murals and associated fixtures out of the Log to the Library’s Special Collections facility. There, the items can be preserved as artifacts for scholarly study, rather than displayed as decorative objects in our alumni and community gathering-space."

Controversy Explanation: Gil-Li Vardi, an Israeli military historian was invited to speak on campus by Ami Pedhazur, a professor og government at the university and director of the university's Institute for Israeli Studies. During the event, a group of pro-Palestinian activists, including a government doctoral student, disrupted the proceedings, reportedly accusing the speakers of promoting Israeli militarism. Pedahzur and the protesters engaged in a heated exchange, which was partially recorded and posted online. Pedahzur later characterized the protest as an attempt to silence the event and intimidate speakers, likening the disruption to the tactics of violent extremists. The graduate student and his supporters accused Pedahzur of physically intimidating them and filed a discrimination complaint against him. It is not clear that the event resumed.
Public Response: High Honors.  The university's president said: "Free discourse is vital to The University of Texas. As a university committed to knowledge and discovery, UT is steadfast in its support of inquiry and debate. Yet free speech also carries with it responsibility. The expression of free speech is not a license to drown out the speech of others, or to shout down ideas one disagrees with. As the University of Chicago states in its 'Principles of Free Expression,' a university 'has a solemn responsibility not only to promote a lively and fearless freedom of debate and deliberation, but also to protect that freedom when others attempt to restrict it.' In this spirit, I appreciate Professor Pedahzur’s work to foster debate and protect freedom of speech for all, including the diverse students he teaches and the visiting scholars he hosts on campus."

Controversy Explanation: Pedahzur, a professor of government at the university and the director of the university's Institute for Israel Studies, hosted and moderated a talk by Gil-Li Vardi, an Israeli military historian. During the event, a group of pro-Palestinian activists, including a government doctoral student, disrupted the proceedings, reportedly accusing the speakers of promoting Israeli militarism. Pedahzur and the protesters engaged in a heated exchange, which was partially recorded and posted online. Pedahzur later characterized the protest as an attempt to silence the event and intimidate speakers, likening the disruption to the tactics of violent extremists. The graduate student and his supporters accused Pedahzur of physically intimidating them and filed a discrimination complaint against him. It is not clear that the event resumed.
Public Response: High Honors.  The university's president said: "Free discourse is vital to The University of Texas. As a university committed to knowledge and discovery, UT is steadfast in its support of inquiry and debate. Yet free speech also carries with it responsibility. The expression of free speech is not a license to drown out the speech of others, or to shout down ideas one disagrees with. As the University of Chicago states in its 'Principles of Free Expression,' a university 'has a solemn responsibility not only to promote a lively and fearless freedom of debate and deliberation, but also to protect that freedom when others attempt to restrict it.' In this spirit, I appreciate Professor Pedahzur’s work to foster debate and protect freedom of speech for all, including the diverse students he teaches and the visiting scholars he hosts on campus."

Controversy Explanation: Nomani, a journalist and activist known for advocating Islamic feminism and criticizing Islamic extremism, was invited to speak at Duke’s Muslim Students Association (MSA) event as part of the university’s "Islamic Awareness Month." Five days before her scheduled talk, the Duke University Center for Activities and Events canceled her appearance following an email from the president of Duke’s Muslim Students Association (MSA) to Muslim students and faculty objections. The email from the MSA criticized Nomani’s views, accused her of having a "nefarious alliance" with so-called Islamophobic speakers, like Ayaan Hirsi Ali and Bill Maher, and cited Omid Safi’s (a professor of Islam at the university) condemnation of her. After Nomani challenged the cancellation and requested evidence against her, the university reversed the decision and reinstated her invitation. Nomani spoke successfully on campus.
Public Response: Disingenuous.  A university spokesperson stated: "Duke is strongly committed to free expression and open discussion of controversial issues... We regret that there was a misunderstanding among our students and staff that made it seem like Ms. Nomani was no longer invited to speak at Duke. Once we became aware of it, Duke immediately let Ms. Nomani know that she was welcomed to speak with our students and the larger community, which she did."

Controversy Explanation: Students protested a campus speech featuring Murray because of Murray's views on race, claiming that the invitation hurt students of color. The university postponed the event indefinitely.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous), Appeased Protesters, Encouraged (Approved of) Self-Censorship. Murray published comments from the university president to Murray's employer in an open letter to university students: "Given the lateness of the semester and the full record of Dr. Murray’s scholarship, I realized we needed more time to prepare for a visit and postponed Wednesday’s conversation. We want to host robust discussions. We have a long history of being in the middle of conversations that matter, but those take time and careful planning."

Controversy Explanation: Some students opposed the selection of Richards as commencement speaker because of Richards' pro-choice positions as president of Planned Parenthood, claiming that Barnard, by inviting Richards to deliver a commencement speech, conveyed the message that students with other views do not matter. Richards spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person.  The university president said: "Richards is a nationally respected leader in the field of women’s health and reproductive rights, and her unwavering dedication in the fight for access and education is a true inspiration.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the law school to rescind its invitation of Malloy because of Malloy's views on abortion and support for gay marriage. Malloy spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Kerry to deliver a commencement speech because of Kerry's views on abortion and his support for gay marriage. Kerry spoke successfully.

Members of the Brandeis community protested and some circulated a petition opposing the university's invitation of Hirsi Ali to deliver a commencement speech, claiming Hirsi Ali's views were anti-Islam. Brandeis rescinded its invitation of Hirsi Ali, claiming it had not previously been aware of her views.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. An official university statement said: "We cannot overlook certain of her past statements that are inconsistent with Brandeis University's core values."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Benjamin to deliver a commencement speech because of Benjamin's views on abortion. Benjamin spoke successfully.

Students protested the university's invitation of Bronson to perform at a spring concert because of Bronson's lyrics about women and rape, which the students called misogynistic. The students also said Bronson has “a history of public transphobia." Students petitioned the university president to disinvite Bronson from participating in the performance. The university canceled the performance.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The program board posted on Facebook: “We apologize to the GW community for causing distress over the past few days and for attempting to bring an artist who is not consistent with our values of diversity and inclusion. . . . Spring fling is intended to be an event for all students to enjoy and including Action Bronson in the day would go against this.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society and local religious leaders opposed Richards, arguing her role as president of Planned Parenthood does not align with traditional Catholic values. The university refused to cancel the event and Richards spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university released a statement in response to the Richards' controversy: "We recognize that the perspectives of some speakers run counter to the Catholic and Jesuit values that animate our university. . . . We work very hard to ensure that these values maintain a privileged place in our community while at the same time providing a forum that does not limit speech either in the content of the view being expressed or the speaker expressing the view."

School: Georgetown University, Walsh School of Foreign Service
Controversy Explanation: In a letter, Undocu Hoyas, a group of undocumented students, asked the university to rescind its invitation of then-Secretary of Homeland Security Johnson to speak at the School of Foreign Service commencement, objecting to Johnson’s role in immigration policy enforcement. Their efforts were joined by other student groups, including Hoyas for Immigrant Rights, and student petitions both for and against having Johnson speak were circulated online. The university didn't waver and Johnson spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. "Johnson . . . has for decades been engaged in critical issues facing our nation and our world, such as homeland security, migration, terrorism, disaster response and more. . . .These are challenges without simple answers and finding solutions requires collaboration, negotiation and compromise among stakeholders and policy makers.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Ferguson to deliver a commencement speech because of Ferguson's support for gay marriage and the influence, in the society's view, of those views on Ferguson's decisions in religious freedom- and free speech-related legal cases. Ferguson spoke successfully.

After students protested the college president's selection of Wong to deliver a commencement speech, the college rescinded its invitation and students and faculty selected a new speaker who could "directly address student concerns" including transphobia, racial issues, and sexual violence.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. The university president said: “In light of the issues our community has been discussing in recent weeks, and the fact that the suggestion of Dr. Wong as a speaker came from me, rather than from students, I felt that this [disinviting Dr. Wong] was the right thing to do."

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Race, Class or Policy Issues
Controversy Explanation: Students in the audience shouted down Bomberger for saying that more black babies are aborted than born alive in New York City. Bomberger resumed speaking, but faced some hostile exchanges during the Q&A.
Students for Trump rescinded its invitation to Yiannopoulos after the university declined to waive an additional $2,000 security fee.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The official statement from the university explained: “Events may require additional facility staffing to address additional service requests and/or risk management concerns at the expense of the organization hosting the event. . . . Physical altercations, bomb threats and threats of weapons violence at other universities where Yiannopoulos has appeared or was scheduled to appear resulted in the need for the Memorial Union to require additional security for the event."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Shriver to deliver a commencement speech because of Shriver's views on abortion and because Shriver's organization, the Save the Children Action Network, "promotes contraception and is reportedly linked to Planned Parenthood." Shriver spoke successfully.
Student LGBTQ groups met with administrators to try to stop Yiannopoulos from speaking on campus due to statements that the groups considered offensive. Yiannopoulos spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral.  The university media relations director said: "The University’s role is to provide a facility, as we would to any of our student groups who go through the event process. Simply providing a facility does not equal an endorsement by the University of any event held on campus."

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Sexuality, Civil Liberties, scientific views, other
Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Clinton to deliver a commencement speech, objecting to Clinton's views on abortion and embryonic research and support for gay marriage and calling Clinton a "poor moral example to the University's students." Clinton spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The university president said:  "[Clinton is] a great statesman [and his commitment to improving the lives of other people should] inspire graduates to seek lives of meaning, purpose and global impact.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Baker to deliver a commencement speech because of Baker's views on abortion, a statewide contraception mandate, and gay marriage. Baker spoke successfully.
Administrators canceled an event featuring Yiannopoulos, citing concerns about the safety of Muslim and LGBT students.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said: “Given what’s happened at a number of campuses by way of altercations, threats and disruptions, the University has serious safety concerns that caused us to determine that we cannot allow the use of university facilities for this event.”

School: New York University, Grossman School of Medicine
Controversy Explanation: After medical students discovered controversial statements Watson made a few years prior about black, female, and obese individuals with respect to genetics research, they wrote a letter to the event sponsor, the Llinas Lecture Organization, expressing their concerns about Watson's appearance. Watson's appearance was canceled.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters.  The lecture series organizers stated: “We agree with the students that this [what Wan said] runs counter to our mission of diversity and inclusion at NYU Langone Medical Center.”

Controversy Explanation: Off-campus individuals objected to Beier's lecture due to her pro-choice views and launched a social media campaign opposing her invitation. In response, the administration canceled Beier's appearance, citing concerns about decorum.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The university provost said: 'There were no specific threats of violence, but I found some of the things being said were quite unsettling. . . .We worried about safety of students, and about perhaps having a guest on campus not be treated right. . . . I hope that our civic discourse here would be respectful to all persons in the future. I felt the behaviors in some of the messages to me were not respectful.”

Controversy Explanation: Faculty, students, and clubs objected to Kennedy's criticism of the film, The Hunting Ground, his views on the scope of campus sexual assault, and his race-related activism, declaring him an "inapproriate" speaker for commencement. The university rejected calls to withdraw its invitation to Kennedy, and Kennedy spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Content of Expression. A university administrator stated: “We sought someone who could engage the important issues raised by student protesters last fall around issues of race and inclusion both on this campus and on campuses across the country . . . Randall Kennedy was chosen because he is a thoughtful and nuanced commentator on race in America.”

Controversy Explanation: Student protesters banged on walls outside the lecture hall where Shapiro was speaking, chanting, "Let us in!" and loudly played the song, "Work," by Rihanna. Shapiro finished his remarks.
A Princeton Committee on Palestine-hosted campus event featuring Israeli-American activist Miko Peled was canceled by the group over Peled’s comments on Twitter, which the group called "antisemitic."

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Farmer to deliver a commencement speech because of Farmer's views on abortion and because Farmer's organization, Partners in Health, promotes the use of contraception. Farmer spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Campbell to deliver a commencement speech because Campbell has advocated for women-priests. Campbell spoke successfully.

During Yiannopoulos' talk multiple students heckled him and smeared fake blood on their faces before walking out. Throughout the event, protesters and attendees repeatedly shouted at each other, mostly accusing Yiannopoulos of being anti-feminist. Yiannopoulos finished his speech.

A professor wrote an open letter addressed to the university president calling for the university to cancel Kelly's performance because of Kelly's "long history of committing violent sexual acts against under-age girls." A student petition, which included the professor's open letter, also called for the performance to be canceled. The university canceled the performance.

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation to Torlakson to deliver a commencement speech because of Torlakson's support for gay marriage and his support for legislation that would require students in California to study the contributions of LGBT Americans. Torlakson spoke successfully.

The university shut down an art exhibit because it included images of the Ku Klux Klan and other potentially disturbing images. Pamphlets at the exhibit explained that the artist intended to stimulate discussion. When student complaints first began, the artist paired informational postings with each painting, covered the door windows of the art museum with paper, and posted a statement on the door indicating that the exhibit could offend some viewers. At a meeting arranged to discuss the work, some students and faculty demanded that the university take the exhibit down. The university temporarily closed the exhibit, then reopened it a few days later with drapes around the KKK painting, presumably to protect students from accidentally viewing it.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. In a statement the chair of art and design said: "We would like to apologize to those in the campus community who have experienced distress resulting from this exhibit. We are sorry. Yesterday’s conversation made clear the strong emotions this exhibit has caused. Art is often intended to spark discussion about societal ills. In this case, it did just that, but we deeply regret the distress it has caused students. We thank the students for sharing their views, and we look forward to working with them to determine how to move forward."

Controversy Explanation:
Students for Justice in Palestine at San Diego State University canceled a talk featuring Peled because of Peled's tweet in response to a 10-year Memorandum of Understanding between the United States and Israel: 
"Then they're surprised Jews have reputation 4being sleazy thieves. #apartheidisrael doesn't need or deserve these $$"

Pro-Palestinian students interrupted Barkat's speech by shouting, forcing police to intervene. Barkat then stepped away from the. podium and spoke privately to a small group of interested students and urged the university president and the San Francisco mayor to not allow speakers to be shouted down in the future.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The university issued a statement that included: “We emphatically assert that all are welcome here. To support an inclusive environment, we encourage our students to engage in thoughtful and respectful dialogue about difficult or controversial issues. While there is a right to dissent, we must also uphold a right to speak and to learn. Unfortunately, members of our community who attended the event were deprived of an opportunity to hear from a speaker invited by a student organization. . . . The students who disrupted the event acted outside the bounds of respectful dialogue and in conflict with [university policy]. … "

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Shriver to deliver a commencement speech because of Shriver's views on abortion and because Shriver's organization, the Save the Children Action Network, "promotes contraception and is reportedly linked to Planned Parenthood." Shriver spoke successfully.

Several Catholic pro-life leaders and the university chapter of Students for Life objected to Pentlicky's views on abortion, arguing they do not align with traditional Catholic thought. Administrators received calls from around the country to expel the members of Nursing Students for Sexual and Reproductive Health, the student organizers who planned to bring Pentlickly to campus. The group canceled the event because it could not meet the administration's request to include more perspectives to counterbalance Pentlicky's.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters, Encouraged (Approved of) Self-Censorship. The university dean wrote: "The promotional materials associated with this event [Pentlicky's speech] were outrageous and offensive to the Catholic character of our university. The way the event was promoted is not acceptable as it denigrates Catholicism and the materials should have never been approved. The event will not be taking place this evening and the students involved in the planning will be looking to include additional viewpoints and perspectives before seeking to reschedule it."

Controversy Explanation: Critics opposed Albright's actions as secretary of state, calling her a war criminal. They petitioned the university to cancel her appearance. Albright spoke successfully.
A professor arranging a film festival disinvited Dotan because of fears of how Boycott Divestment Sanctions supporters would react to the views expressed in Dotan's films.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The provost responded to the controversy in a university wide email: "I feel it necessary to reaffirm our commitment to intellectual and respectful debate on controversial issues."

Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the university to cancel an event featuring Spencer organized by an off-campus private group on the grounds that Spencer is a white nationalist. Spencer spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Views, Appeased Protesters. The university president said:  "To be clear, Texas A&M University -- including faculty, staff, students and/or student groups -- did not invite this speaker to our campus nor do we endorse his rhetoric in any way. In fact, our leadership finds his views as expressed to date in direct conflict with our core values."

Controversy Explanation: Students opposed Bronson's lyrics because of their portrayal of women and rape, and they petitioned the college to rescind its invitation of Bronson to perform on campus. The college canceled the performance.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The student government committee that invited Bronson, stated on Facebook, along with the announcement that Bronson's invitation had been revoked, that: “The very act of bringing him to this campus runs counter to the College’s obligation to protect the emotional and physical safety of its students.”

Controversy Explanation: The administration allegedly asked Tigers for Liberty to refrain from promoting an event featuring Yiannopolous either on campus or on social media. Tigers for Liberty was also asked to provide $1,600 for event security that it raised in a GoFundMe campaign. Yiannopoulos spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The president of the university said: “We want Trinity to be a free marketplace of ideas, where contentious topics can be discussed intellectually and civilly. While not everyone at Trinity or everyone in Tigers for Liberty may agree with what the speaker has to say, it is important that we address these ideas head on in the pursuit of truth.”

Controversy Explanation: Students and faculty petitioned the university to disinvite Sessions because of Sessions' support for then-presidential candidate Donald Trump. Sessions spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person.  An official university statement included: "The Honorable Jeff Sessions has ably served the people of Alabama as United States Senator since 1997, and was the unanimous choice for Commencement speaker of a diverse selection committee that represents students, faculty and staff . . . As a university that values inclusiveness, we welcome Senator Sessions with the respect and civility that he and his office deserve."

Controversy Explanation: Students, alumni, and members of the public protested Deek's talk, objecting to his "settler-colonial agenda that is xenophobic, Islamophobic, and anti-Black." When Deek began his talk, about 30 protesters interrupted with loud shouts and marched to the front of the room, blocking Deek from the audience with a large banner that read, "1948 = 1492." Deek finished his remarks.

Students, student groups, faculty, and alumni petitioned the administration to cancel Shkreli's speech, calling Shkreli a criminal and a sexist. Graduate students, represented by the academic student workers union, filed grievances with labor relations, claiming the event violated their contract by fostering an unsafe work environment and that it violated California law, which prohibits harassment against protected categories. Shortly before the speech, protesters blocked the entrances. One person was arrested. The College Republicans, the event sponsor, canceled the event 30 minutes before it was scheduled to begin after discussions with the university police department and student affairs officials.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The interim university chancellor said: “I am deeply disappointed with the events of this evening. . . .Our community is founded on principles of respect for all views, even those that we personally find repellent. As I have stated repeatedly, a university is at its best when it listens to and critically engages opposing views, especially ones that many of us find upsetting or even offensive.”

Controversy Explanation: Students, student groups, faculty, and alumni petitioned the administration to cancel Yiannopoulos' speech, describing him as racist, sexist, and Islamophobic. Graduate students, represented by the academic student workers union, filed grievances with labor relations, claiming the event violated their contract by fostering an unsafe work environment and that it violated California law, which prohibits harassment against protected categories. Shortly before the speech, protesters blocked the entrances. One person was arrested and the event was canceled 30 minutes before it was scheduled to start.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The interim university chancellor said: “I am deeply disappointed with the events of this evening. . . .Our community is founded on principles of respect for all views, even those that we personally find repellent. As I have stated repeatedly, a university is at its best when it listens to and critically engages opposing views, especially ones that many of us find upsetting or even offensive.”

Controversy Explanation: Students organized a petition demanding that Yiannopoulos' "hate speech"event be canceled. Protests occurred outside the event hall, but Yiannopoulos spoke successfully. The College Republicans were suspended from holding events on campus for a full year after the event for not having insurance for the service providers (e.g. security) at the event.
A screening of the documentary, Can We Take a Joke?,  was interrupted 40 minutes in when someone pulled the fire alarm. There was no fire, but the rest of the movie was not shown.

Students and community Black Lives Matter protesters forced Alvarez' speech to end after 20 minutes because of nonstop heckling. Protesters considered Alvarez, in her capacity as Cook County state's attorney, responsible for state violence against minorities.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. A director of the Institute of Politics stated in a statement sent to the school paper: “At the Institute of Politics, we understand and respect that members of our community have passionate views that may conflict with those of our guest speakers, so we seek to create a climate in which all these views can be expressed in a respectful manner. We are deeply disappointed that a group of protesters disrupted our event . . . to such an extent that a discussion was unable to take place.” After the event, the Executive Director is reported as saying: “The University of Chicago prides itself on free and open inquiry, rigorous discussion and questions about challenging issues… they can listen even when they deeply disagree with the issue and do so really substantively. That is something we need to do with every issue including the future of the state attorney’s office."

Controversy Explanation: Students advocating for the Palestinian cause shouted at Eid for his views on Israel. Police removed the protesters and Eid, ending the event early.
UChicago Students for Life canceled an event featuring Bomberger, a pro-life speaker, citing concerns about organized protest and disruption.

Students started two petitions: one, asking the university to cancel the event; the other, asking it to move the event off campus. Both claimed that Yiannopoulos' speeches are filled with bigotry and hatefulness. Yiannopoulos spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university chancellor said: “Personally, I feel strongly that discrimination and harassment have no place on our campus. . . . . With that said, we must support the free exchange of ideas. . . ."

Controversy Topic(s): Gender, Political Views, Race, Religion, Scientific Views
Controversy Explanation: Alumni petitioned the administration to disinvite Yiannopoulos. Students and nonstudents counter-petitioned. The university refused to disinvite Yiannopoulos and he spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The university president wrote in an op-ed: “The right to free speech protects every one of us, no matter how popular or unpopular our views might be. . . . . In the same way, our commitment to diversity means that we must respect the unique perspective each one of us brings to the public conversation. If we think we can sacrifice either diversity or free speech to preserve the other, we deserve neither.”

Controversy Explanation: Terps for Trump canceled Yiannopoulos' speech due to the security costs imposed by the university. The organizing group had earned almost enough to cover the anticipated costs when it revoked the invitation.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson stated: "[T]he event ​was never officially confirmed, ​so security wasn't confirmed either."

Controversy Explanation: The College Republicans canceled an event featuring Yiannopoulos in the early planning stages because university administrators said security would cost $22,000; an estimate based on disruptions of Yiannopoulos events at other campuses.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The university issued a statement that said: “The College Republicans student organization was approached about hosting an event with Milo Yiannopoulos. The College Republicans met with University of Miami staff to review operations and logistics needed to host the speaker. The College Republicans decided not to pursue the event."

Controversy Explanation: Students, staff, faculty, and community members protested Yiannopoulos' invitation and then his speech. During his speech, Yiannopoulos was interrupted multiple times including by the use of air horns. Yiannopoulos finished his remarks.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university president said in a state of the university address shortly after the Yiannopoulos event: "I am opposed to hate speech of any kind." But he also said, "While the university encourages all members of the community to speak with respect and understanding of others, we should not forbid speech that shocks, hurts or angers. . . .We must not tolerate the shouting down of points of view as we've seen in our community in recent months."

Controversy Explanation: A faculty member invited Clarke to give the keynote address at a symposium on officer-involved shootings. The faculty member then rescinded Clarke's invitation because the university had concerns about Clarke's views on Black Lives Matter. The university claimed Clarke was never "officially invited" to speak on campus because his travel and accommodation demands were too difficult to satisfy. The university eventually admitted openly that they decided not to finalize Clarke's appearance because his views were “potentially politically polarizing."
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. A university statement to the school paper included: "we decided not to finalize his arrangements to visit campus when it was determined his appearance could potentially become politically polarizing in light of the imminent presidential election."

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Health, Scientific Views, Sexuality, Civil Liberties, other
Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society and a local bishop condemned the university for honoring then-Vice President Biden (and John Boehner), and 89 students signed op-eds protesting Biden and Boehner being awarded the Laetare Medal and being invited to speak at commencement by the university. The students objected to Biden, specifically, because he holds views outside the Catholic Church's traditional teachings. They objected to the fact that Biden allocated federal funding for embryonic stem cell research, voted against a ban on human cloning, embraced gay marriage, and supported the HHS mandate, which requires religious institutions to include coverage for contraceptives and abortifacients in its healthcare plans. Biden spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university president said at the commencement ceremony: "Each of you [Biden and Boehner], we must acknowledge, has cast votes and taken positions about which many among us have reservations – in some cases, grave moral reservations . . . We award you today the Laetare Medal not to endorse particular positions you've taken or votes you've cast, but because each of you have given your lives to serve the common good of political leadership by your own best light."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society and a local bishop condemned the university for honoring Boehner (and then-Vice President Joe Biden), and 89 students signed op-eds protesting their being awarded the Laetare Medal and being invited to speak at commencement by the university. The students objected to Boehner, specifically, because of his positions on immigration, the death penalty, and environmental issues. Boehner spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university president said at the commencement ceremony: "Each of you [Biden and Boehner], we must acknowledge, has cast votes and taken positions about which many among us have reservations – in some cases, grave moral reservations . . . We award you today the Laetare Medal not to endorse particular positions you've taken or votes you've cast, but because each of you have given your lives to serve the common good of political leadership by your own best light."

School: University of Pennsylvania, Fels Institute of Government in partnership with Penn Law
Source(s): Activist(s), General Public, Student Group(s), Student(s)
Controversy Explanation: Protesters shouted at Brennan multiple times over his actions as CIA head, particularly his involvement in wars in the Middle East and drone strikes. Campus police removed at least six protesters. The moderator from the Fels Institute of Government Administration and the dean of Penn Law spoke up for free speech but were quickly drowned out by protesters, leading them to cancel the remainder of the event.
Public Response: Neutral. The law school dean reminded the audience of the University of Pennsylvania Free Speech Policy and asked: “Are you trying to silence him?”

Controversy Explanation: Students and faculty claimed Bush was unqualified to speak at commencement because of her politics. Bush declined the invitation after the pushback.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The college dean said: "Mrs. Bush is quite qualified to be the school’s commencement speaker."

Controversy Explanation: The university rescinded its invitation of Goodwin to deliver a commencement speech after Goodwin admitted to committing plagiarism and students complained.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. The university president stated: "We thought better to just cancel the appearance than to have her talk in front of our students and their families."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation of Wise to deliver a commencement speech because of Wise's views on abortion. Wise spoke successfully.
Members of the Black Student Union demanded the mural, which depicts a Ku Klux Klan rally, be removed. The university refused to remove the mural.
Public Response: Neutral.  In a statement the university's chancellor said: "The major issue running throughout all of the discussions and conversations over these last several weeks is not, in fact, the Benton mural. It is instead the state of diversity on our campus. The real issue, the real test of character, for Indiana University Bloomington is the strength of its commitment to diversity."

Controversy Explanation: Students and the Associated Student Body did not want the mural, depicting the wealthy sitting on toilets, defecating on huddled masses of poor people below, hung in the college's student center. An agreement was made to sell the mural but the college's mural program asked that it not be sold. The mural was relocated to the art department.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters.  In a statement the college's interim president said: “It’s a way of improving a lecture hall that has decor and colors from the ’70s.” He later added, “Art has a way of getting recycled over time. It could go down for another display and then get put back up again.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cornell Review and the College Republicans invited Coulter to speak about the controversy over the Confederate flag flying above South Carolina's state capitol. Students opposed Coulter's views on race and the Confederate flag. Coulter was heckled throughout her speech and, during the Q&A, oranges were thrown at the podium and the stage. One audience member lunged at the platform where Coulter was standing, but campus police restrained him and removed him from the room. A different auidience member then began talking over Coulter. Coulter left before finishing her speech.

The university decided it would not sponsor a performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, on campus because the play espouses beliefs contrary to Catholic Church doctrine. The university woman's group sponsoring the event moved it to a hotel ballroom and put on the event without the university as a sponsor.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. The university president, when refusing to permit the event on campus, said allowing plays to be performed "speaks volumes about who we are, what are mission is, what we believe."

Controversy Explanation: After the play, The Vagina Monologues, was performed on campus the year prior, the university prohibited performances of the play on campus after alumni raised concerns. Students performed the play in defiance of the ban.
Religious groups including Priests For Life asked the university to rescind its honorary degree to Cross because of Cross' pro-choice views. The university refused to rescind Cross' honorary degree.
Public Response: Supported Content of Expression. A university spokesperson stated: "Charity and justice demand that we take her at her word.”

Controversy Explanation: Students contested the university's invitation of Fiorina to deliver a commencement speech, claiming Fiorina's business background meant she was not an inclusive choice. Fiorina spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The university president said: "She meets all of our expectations and more."

Controversy Explanation: Students opposed the university's choice of Bush as commencement speaker because of Bush's conservative views. Bush's speech proceeded largely uninterrupted.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The university president introduced Bush with the following: "Few families have so devotedly exemplified the university's commitment to public service as yours.. . . . interpersonal skills . . . commitment to inclusiveness, combined with your pragmatism and common sense, inspires us to hope that your presidency will expand opportunity for all Americans and bring peace and prosperity to the wider world."

Controversy Explanation: Police officer groups and family members of the victim opposed the college's invitation of Abu-Jamal to campus to deliver a commencement speech because Abu-Jamal was on death row at the time for killing a police officer. Abu Jamal spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Content of Expression. The college president said: "Many find, from looking at the record, the trial transcript and the various briefs filed in Abu Jamal's behalf, that the essential fairness of the case warrants critical discussion."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Foglietta to deliver a commencement speech because of Foglietta's views on abortion. Foglietta spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Marro to deliever a commencement speech because of Marro's views on abortion and, according to the society, Marro's bias against Catholics and Jews. Marro spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Johnson to deliver a commencement speech because of Johnson's endorsement of the “morning after” pill. Johnson spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation to Edelman to deliver a commencement speech because Edelman's organization, the Children's Defense Fund, promoted contraceptives in public school health clinics. Edelman spoke successfully.

Students accused Albright of war crimes and demanded that the university president disinvite her from campus. Some students walked out during Albright's speech, while others walked through the crowd holding signs. One protester yelled objections during Albright's keynote address. Some of the protesters were removed from the event and escorted off the premises.
The university president did not permit a Planned Parenthood representative to speak on campus because of the organization's pro-choice views.
Public Response: Mistaken on the Law. The president of the university published an op-ed that starts: "Censorship concerns the banning of ideas or viewpoints. Sponsorship is concerned with organizations making use of another organization's name and facilities. Normally, non-sponsorship occurs not because of an organization's ideas, or even because of its people, but rather because of its actions.

Controversy Explanation: Greene believes she was disinvited by the university administration because of her books, which discuss feminism, sexuality, and war.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. The university told Greene her invitation was revoked because her “ideas may be different from the ideas of Harding University."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation of Winkler to deliver a commencement speech because of Winkler's views on abortion. Winkler spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the college's invitation of Kerrey to deliver a commencement speech because of Kerrey's pro-choice views. Kerrey spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation of Nelson to deliver a commencement speech because of Nelson's views on population growth. Nelson spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation of Mitchell to deliver a commencement speech because of Mitchell's views on abortion, parental notification, and fetal tissue research. Mitchell spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the college's invitation of Jackson to deliver a commencement speech because of Jackson's pro-choice views. Jackson spoke successfully.
Students petitioned the university to replace Rogers as its commencement speaker because they felt he wasn't a mature choice. Rogers spoke without disruption.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. An administrative statement included: "He [Mr. Rogers] has earned every major award in the television industry, including two George Foster Peabody Awards."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Willis to deliver a commencement speech because of Willis' views on abortion, contraception, and priestly celibacy. Willis spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Castro to deliver a commencement speech because of Castro's views on abortion. Castro spoke successfully.

The college administration revoked Tammeus' invitation to speak at commencnement after the Cardinal Newman Society declared Tammeus an "offending" speaker who violates  “Ex Corde Ecclesia,” a 1990 Vatican document stipulating tighter restrictions on church-connected colleges, becasue Tammeus had written a series of reports on Catholic priests and AIDS for the Kansas City Star and had also written critically of Catholic practices and doctrines.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation to Caldera to deliver a commencement speech because of Caldera's views on abortion and gay rights. Caldera spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Leahy to deliver a commencement speech because of Leahy's views on abortion. Leahy spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Garibaldi to deliver a commencement speech because of Garibaldi's backing of "right-to-die" rulings. Garibaldi spoke successfully.
Protesters called Albright a war criminal and said she was unwelcome at Berkeley. Albright finished the speech but was heckled throughout.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation to Annan to deliver a commencement speech because of Annan's views on abortion.

Kissinger withdrew from a speaking event set to take place at the Lyndon Baines Johnson Presidential Library, located on campus, because the university told him that planned protests against his foreign policy would "endanger public safety." A journalism professor who had organized a student teach-in to plan questions for Kissinger disputed the chancellor's assertion that student's were planning a violent protest. The professor told reporters that the students were “not trying to shut it down . . .[but] were trying to get [Kissinger] to speak more.”
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The university chancellor stated: “It is deeply disturbing that any group of people can, by threatening to endanger public safety, dictate to a university community who can and cannot be heard.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation to Reno to deliver a commencement speech because of Reno's views on abortion and because her department allegedly targeted pro-life protesters. Reno spoke successfully.

Pro-life students and alumni objected to the university's invitation of Quindlen to deliver a commencement speech because of Quindlen's pro-choice views. Quindlen withdrew from speaking at commencement.
Public Response: None. An article reported that "University officials declined to comment on her decision."

Controversy Explanation: Turner, media mogul and owner of the Atlanta Braves baseball team, withdrew from delivering a commencement speech because of student protests over the Braves' team mascot.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship. The college president said in a statement: “As a result of the comments made about our decision to invite Mr. Turner, we have all gained a keener insight into the concerns many in the community have about Native American issues on campus, both in the curriculum and in other areas.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Favreau to deliver a commencement speech because of Favreau's views on religious freedom and his support for gay marriage. Favreau spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the college to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Foreign Affairs, Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
Controversy Explanation: The national Amnesty International office and students demanded that the student chapter of Amnesty International disinvite Dershowitz from a speaking engagement. Dershowitz spoke at a different student group's event.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

TFP Student Action, an off-campus organization, started a petition protesting the university's invitation of Breyer to deliver an address at the 20th Annual Clifford Symposium. They asked the university to cancel the talk because of Breyer's pro-choice views and his vote to uphold partial-birth abortion. The petition garnered more than 24,000 signatures. Breyer spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Newsom to deliver a commencement speech because of Newsom's views on abortion. Newsom spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues. Student Affairs did not approve the performance, so the student organizers held it off campus instead.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Lew because of Lew's support for a contraception mandate in the Affordable Care Act. Lew spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

Controversy Topic(s): Criminal or Other Misconduct, Police, Race
Controversy Explanation: Community members, politicians, the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections, and the Vermont Troopers Association pushed for a disinvitation and condemned Abu-Jamal's selection as commencement speaker because of Abu-Jamal's conviction for killing a police officer. Abu-Jamal spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral. The college’s interim president said that in choosing Abu-Jamal as their speaker students showed “how this newest group of Goddard graduates expresses their freedom to engage and think radically and critically in a world that often sets up barriers to do just that.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation to Madsen because of Madsen's views on abortion. Madsen spoke successfully.

Students decried the university's invitation of Bloomberg, objecting to Bloomberg's support for "stop-and-frisk" policies and surveillance after 9/11. Despite some heckling during his speech, Bloomberg spoke successfully.

School: Harvard University Graduate School of Education
Controversy Explanation: Students and alumni protested Johnston's support for test-based teacher accountability, asking the graduate school to revoke its invitation of Johnston to deliver a commencement speech. Johnston spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
