Neutral. The dean of the graduate school issued a statement: "it is precisely because there is debate about his positions that we should welcome the opportunity to hear from him.”

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Class or Policy Issues, Police
Controversy Explanation: Students, faculty, and alumni protested the college's invitation of Birgeneau to deliver a commencement speech because Birgeneau was the chancellor at Berkeley when campus police responded with force against an "Occupy" protest in 2011. Birgeneau refused to respond to a list of student and alumni demands and withdrew from speaking at commencement.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. President of the college is reported as saying that while he appreciated the views of the protesters, "it is nonetheless deeply regrettable that we have lost an opportunity to recognize and hear from one of the most consequential leaders in American higher education.”

Controversy Explanation: For the grand opening of a new on-campus museum of art, the university comissioned a Georgia State University professor to create an art installation chronicling the history of Corra Harris' homestead, a piece of land that the university was gifted in 2009. The installation highlighted Harris' "complicated legacy" by including parts of an 1899 magazine article in which Harris rationalized lynching and called African-Americans "savage brutes." Before the museum opening, the university president ordered the installation removed. Two weeks later, following protests and a petition calling for the reinstallation of the display, the university reinstalled the display.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression.A university statement said: "Yesterday, during a preview tour of the [museum], concerns were raised that the subject matter of one proposed exhibit, Ruth Stanford’s “A Walk in the Valley,” is not aligned with the celebratory atmosphere of the museum’s opening. We therefore made the decision to display the exhibit at a more appropriate later time."

Controversy Explanation: Students protested Napolitano's role in the deportation of illegal immigrants when she was chief of Homeland Security. The student government passed a resolution asking that Napolitano be disinvited from commencement, but the college refused. Heckling occurred throughout Napolitano's remarks. Napolitano was able to finish her speech, but some audience members complained that they could not hear anything she said.

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Reese to deliver a commencement speech because of Reese's views on abortion, the Affordable Care Act, and gay marriage. Reese spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation to Shriver to deliver a commencement speech because of Shriver's views on abortion. Shriver spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Gergen because of Gergen's views on abortion. Gergen spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.
A column by Will on campus sexual assault led students and faculty to petition the administration to rescind Will's invitation. Will spoke without major incident.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. A university statement explained: "As an institution of higher education, we stress the importance of engaging in open, respectful, intellectual dialogue about the challenges facing our campuses and our country.

Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the university to disinvite Will from speaking at commencement because of a column Will had written regarding campus sexual assault. Nondisruptive protests occurred both inside and outside the event, but Will spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The university president stated: "Great universities are committed to serving the public good by creating space for discourse and exchange of ideas, though that exchange may be uncomfortable and will sometimes challenge values and beliefs. There is no mandate to agree, only to serve society by allowing learning to take place. If universities do not hold onto this, we do not serve the greater good. Because next time it will be a different speaker and a different issue, and the dividing lines will not be the same."

Controversy Explanation: Students and faculty contended that the university should not give a platform to Gianforte and his wife to speak at commencement because of their opposition to LGBT nondiscrimination statutes and their financial contributions to the faith-based Glendive Dinosaur Fossil Museum, which teaches that humans co-existed with dinosaurs. Gianforte spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person.  The university chancellor told a reporter via email that it was unfair to call the Gianfortes "anti-science" because they are "great supporters of science and . . . science and math have been part of their very successful business ventures."

Controversy Explanation: Students and faculty protested the university's invitation of Gianforte and her husband to speak at commencement due to their opposition to LGBT nondiscrimination statutes and their financial contributions to the faith-based Glendive Dinosaur Fossil Museum, which teaches that humans co-existed with dinosaurs. Gianforte spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Content of Expression.  The university chancellor told a reporter via email that it was unfair to call the Gianfortes "anti-science" because they are "great supporters of science and . . . science and math have been part of their very successful business ventures."

School: New York School of Visual Arts
Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the school to remove the image, Dolphin Rape Cave, that was featured in a rotating display organized by members of the School of Visual Arts, objecting to its depiction of sexual assault. The school did not remove the artwork.
Public Response: Neutral. The chair of the photography department issued a statement: "As a department, we encourage and nurture the making of meaningful images, based on their [the artists'] individual agendas, experiences, ambitions, and occasionally work that addresses difficult social issues Often, this can result in provocative, indeed, wounded gestures. To prohibit the appearance of any image would sabotage this simple mandate."

Controversy Explanation: An online student petition called on the university to cancel an event called "Circus Spectacular," saying it "has been cited numerous times for failing to meet minimum Animal Welfare Act standards, as documented by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals." The petition garnered more than 2,500 signatures and the university canceled the performance.

The college rescinded its invitation of Black to deliver a commencement speech after the board of trustees objected to explicit photographs of Black that had been circulated on the Internet. Black was reinvited after the college faced widespread criticism. Black accepted the reinvitation and spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. According to Black, administrators uninvited him because: "I was involved in a ‘scandal’ in 2009 regarding extremely personal photographs that were put up on Internet gossip sites of me and my ex-boyfriend."

Controversy Explanation: University administrators removed a panel of an interactive art installation, The Surface, which was intended to be drawn on by those who viewed the exhibit. On the panel that was removed, someone had drawn a penis which someone else had painted over.

The college banned performances of the play, The Vagina Monologues, on campus in 2006 because "its depiction of female sexuality is so deeply at odds with the true meaning and morality that the Catholic Church’s teaching celebrates." Students performed the play off campus for the eighth year straight.

Students and faculty protested the university's invitation of Rice to deliver a commencement speech and asked the university to rescind Rice's invitation to speak at commencement because Rice "played a prominent role in his administration’s efforts to mislead the American people about the presence of weapons of mass destruction in Iraq and the existence of links between al Qaeda and the Iraqi regime." Rice withdrew in the face of opposition, citing the desire not to be a distraction in a moment of celebration.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. A statement from the university said: "Dr. Rice is a highly accomplished and respected diplomat, scholar and author, and we are excited that she has agreed to address our graduates and guests at commencement."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Campbell to deliver a commencement speech because of Campbell's views on abortion, signing of a letter "honoring and celebrating" the life of Dr. George Tiller, and support of a 1993 healthcare reform bill. Campbell spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Blatz to deliver a commencement speech because of Blatz' support for gay marriage. Blatz spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Hollenbach because of Hollenbach's views on the implementation of a law requiring theologians to teach authentic Catholic doctrine and Hollenbach's support of the nomination of Kathleen Sebelius as Health and Human Services Secretary. Sebelius spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the college to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Mayotte to deliver a commencement speech because of Mayotte's views on abortion and birth control.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Fulop because of Fulop's support for same-sex marriage. Fulop spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Sobrino to deliver a commencement speech because of Sobrino's views on the divinity of Jesus Christ. Sobrino spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

Will was invited to speak as part of the Elizabeth Hubert Malott Public Affairs Program, a program based on the belief "“that a range of opinions about the world — especially opinions with which we may not agree, or think we do not agree — leads to a better educational experience.” After a column on campus sexual assault written by Will offended many, college administrators canceled the event.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist), Appeased Protesters.  The university president said: "Sexual assault is not a conservative or liberal issue. And it is too important to be trivialized in a political debate or wrapped into a celebrity controversy. For that reason, after Mr. Will authored a column questioning the validity of a specific sexual assault case that reflects similar experiences reported by Scripps students, we decided not to finalize the speaker agreement. . . ."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Gender, Health
Controversy Explanation: Faculty members asked the university to rescind its invitation of Eberstadt to deliver a commencement speech, objecting to Eberstadt's comments about working mothers. Eberstadt spoke successfully.

Students protested the college's invitation of Lagarde to deliver a commencement speech, claiming Lagarde "represents a corrupt system that fuels the oppression and abuse of women worldwide." Lagarde withdrew to "preserve the celebratory spirit" of graduation.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The college president published an official statement that included: "Those who objected will be satisfied that their activism has had a desired effect. But at what cost to Smith College? This is a question I hope we will ponder as a community in the months ahead. . . .  I stand behind the decision of Smith’s Board of Trustees, of which I am a member, to invite Mme. Lagarde to serve as our speaker and to receive an honorary degree. . . . I want to underscore this fact: An invitation to speak at a commencement is not an endorsement of all views or policies of an individual or the institution she or he leads. Such a test would preclude virtually anyone in public office or position of influence. Moreover, such a test would seem anathema to our core values of free thought and diversity of opinion. I remain committed to leading a college where differing views can be heard and debated with respect."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Evans to deliver a commencement speech because of Evans' views on birth control.  Evans spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The university interim president called Evans a “role model.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Panetta to deliver a commencement speech because of Panetta's views on abortion. Panetta spoke successfully.

The co-chairs of the Stanford American Indian Organization met with the student director and student co-producers of the play, Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson, to express concern over how the play represented Native Americans and issues such as depression, suicide, and alcoholism. After a month of meetings where student organizers considered altering the script and Native American activists threatened to protest, the director and co-producers decided not to perform the play and instead staged a musical cabaret titled, Did We Offend You?

Students protested the university's invitation of Foxman to deliver a commencement speech because of Foxman's statements about Muslims and his opposition to recognizing the Armenian Genocide. Foxman spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. A spokesperson from the university president's office said: “Mr. Foxman’s body of work is well deserving of recognition. . . . It is our hope that Mr. Foxman’s personal story as a Holocaust survivor and attorney who has dedicated his life to public service will inspire our graduates as they embark on their professional careers.”

School: Tufts University, The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy
Controversy Explanation: Students for Justice in Palestine petitioned the university to cancel an event featuring Shamir-Borer, the Israeli Defense Force's legal advisor during Operation Protective Edge, which resulted in the deaths of 2,127 Palestinians in Gaza. Shamir-Borer spoke successfully while students protested outside.

The Berkeley Forum invited Thiel to discuss his views on political protest with students. Protesters broke into the venue and shouted Thiel down because "Thiel’s Palantir [Technologies, a computer software company] is funded by CIA. Spies on people so they can rape forcefeed you through your ass," even though Thiel is opposed to intrusive government and supports policies that uphold civil liberties against the security policies of the federal government.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The president of the Berkeley Forum said: “We honestly didn't think the protests would interfere. . . .It’s pretty unimaginable and unfortunate. I'm in support of free speech, but this is not the right venue for that [kind of disruptive protest]. I'm very disappointed.”

Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the university to rescind its invitation of then-President Trump to commencement, citing Trump's "crude and unforgiving" remarks about women and minorities, his "anti-Muslim" campaign, and his immigration travel ban and calling him "the antithesis of Christian values." Trump spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Berry to deliver a commencement speech because of Berry's support for gay marriage. Berry spoke successfully.

A Catholic activist group, Church Militant, launched a media campaign to have the university revoke Copeland's speaking invitation, claiming Copeland supports gay rights. After public outcry, a mutual decision was reached to cancel Copeland's lecture.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The head of the Center that invited Copeland said: “We are sorry for this lost educational opportunity for Madonna students, and for the heavy blow it strikes to academic freedom and to Pope Francis’ vision for the Church.”

Controversy Explanation: Students asked the university to cancel an event featuring Shapiro, claiming Shapiro made a career of "perpetuating racism and xenophobia and actively fighting against human dignity.” A faculty member suggested students protest by reserving seats and not showing up. Shapiro spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral. The university released a statement: "We have addressed this issue [a professor suggested protestors reserve seats] with the staff member internally and will work to make sure that interested students have an opportunity to see Ben Shapiro on February 8."

Controversy Explanation: TFP Student Action, an off-campus group, started a petition opposing a Pride Prom event. The petition included a pre-drafted letter addressed to the university president and garnered more than 18,500 signatures. The event proceeded as planned.

Alumni petitioned the president to cancel Murray's talk. At the talk, students shouted down Murray once he took the stage, forcing college officials to relocate the event to a private, remote location with only Murray and professor Allison Stanger present. Protesters became aware of the new location and attacked Murray and Stanger as they tried to leave campus, surrounding their car. Someone pulled Stanger's hair so hard she ended up in the emergency room with a neck injury. The university disciplined 74 students.
Public Response: Condemned Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university president spoke before Murray got up on stage. An article reported that "she [the university president] was applauded when she said she disagreed with Murray's views . . . but she also said that 'the very premise of free speech on this campus is that a speaker has a right to be heard.'" In multiple public statements after the event, the university president seemed to be admonishing the disruptive protests she had tried to appease before the event: "Free speech lies at the heart of our purpose as an institution, and we cannot allow force or disruption to undermine it."

Controversy Explanation: Several off-campus groups — including the Coalition of Concerned Catholics, TFP Student Action, and Church Militant — petitioned the university to disinvite Martin from delivering a commencement speech, objecting to Martin's views on LGBT issues. The university refused to revoke its invitation to Martin and Martin spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral.  A university spokesperson said: “Misericordia University is a Catholic institution established in the traditions of the Sisters of Mercy. . . We are committed to a mission of fostering intellectual curiosity, critical thinking and respect for everyone in an environment where all are welcome.”

Controversy Explanation: Less than a week before a Students for Academic Freedom event featuring Horowitz, the administration informed the group that it would be required to cover the cost of security deemed necessary by the university police department because of "planned counter--protests." Following a letter from FIRE, the university agreed to cover the security costs and Horowitz spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The chancellor said: "The administration supports all student groups in the learning experience of planning and sponsoring a wide variety of events. The University honors the students’ First Amendment rights and does not engage in censorship of those events irrespective of whether we share the speaker’s viewpoint."

Controversy Explanation: Students opposed the College Republicans' invitation of McInnes because of comments McInnes made regarding race and sexual orientation. McInnes was forced to stop speaking after the event was repeatedly disrupted by a protest group formed in response to McInnes's invitation, NYU Anti-Fascists, and fights broke out, leading to multiple arrests and McInnes getting sprayed with pepper spray.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous).  After the event a university spokesperson said: “Our principle at NYU is somebody who comes here to speak — who’s invited by a student organization — should have an opportunity to speak, but this event reflected well on no one.”

Controversy Explanation: The NYU College Republicans withdrew its invitation to Merse, citing safety concerns, administrative pressure over Merse's ties to alleged hate groups, and Merse's Islamophobic rhetoric.

Students and student groups, including the Alliance of Jewish Progressives and Allies, protested and petitioned to have Hotovely's talk canceled, claiming that Hotovely's denial of Palestinian historical claims to Israel and her policies are racist. The Princeton Center for Jewish Life, who had invited Hotovely, rescinded its invitation. A different Jewish student group, Chabad House, invited Hotovely to speak on the originally scheduled day, and she spoke successfully
The university canceled a campus event featuring Block after protesters, objecting to Block’s statements regarding slavery, threatened to disrupt the event.

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Boyle to deliver a commencement speech because of Boyle's support for gay marriage and his repudiation of the Church's ban on the ordination of women. Boyle spoke successfully.
Kilbourne claimed that the college revoked her invitation to speak at commencement because of an award she received from Planned Parenthood more than a decade earlier.
Public Response: None. A college spokesperson said: “We consider our deliberations about, and discussions with, prospective college commencement speakers to be private.”

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Gender, Immigration, Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Political Views, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: The College Republicans claimed the university put up bureaucratic roadblocks to having Yiannopoulos speak on campus, including by suggesting a time when it knew Yiannopoulos was touring at the other side of the country. Students also expressed opposition to Yiannopoulos' presence on campus because they perceived his rhetoric as offensive to marginalized groups.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The chief communications officer released a statement that said: “The university has offered to work with the student organization to possibly host the speaker by reviewing alternative dates during the academic year,” she said in the email. “Should alternative dates be considered…proper lead time will need to be factored in for the university and (SDSUPD) to conduct its due diligence and security needs assessment.”

Controversy Explanation: TFP Student Action, an off-campus organization, petitioned the university rescind its invitation to Cornwall because of Cornwall's avowed transgender activism. The petition garnered more than 13,000 signatures. The administration refused to cancel the event and provided extra security. Cornwall spoke successfully.

School: Santa Clara University School of Law
Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Panetta to deliver a commencement speech because of Panetta's views on abortion. Panetta spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The dean said that Panetta is "a tremendous role model [and that his] decades of ethical leadership and public service. His career exemplifies our University’s Jesuit ethos of putting one’s talents to work in service to others. . . . At every turn he has endeavored to create a more just, humane, and sustainable world.”

Controversy Explanation: Nonstudent activists started a petition demanding that the college rescind its invitation of Martin to speak at commencement because of Martin's acceptance of homosexuality. Martin spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. "There is room in our Church for honest differences in how true followers of Christ understand and adhere to His teaching. All of humanity is created in the Image and Likeness of God, and Fr. Martin invites those of differing perspectives to explore opportunities for increasing understanding through respectful dialogue. That approach most definitely is consistent with the expectations of the contemplative discernment processes espoused in Jesuit teaching."

Controversy Explanation: Students and faculty petitioned the student government to rescind funding for the Spencer event, claiming that Spencer is prejudiced against Muslims. Spencer spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The president and provost issued a joint statement that included: "We believe that, rather than being in opposition, free expression and an inclusive culture are essential parts of the same whole. In a truly inclusive culture, everyone in our diverse community, from all backgrounds and perspectives, has a voice and feels empowered to participate in active debate."

Controversy Topic(s): Health, Immigration, Political Views, Race, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the university to revoke its invitation of Cornyn to speak at commencement because of Cornyn's support of then-President Trump, voter ID laws, and efforts to block funding for "sanctuary cities." Administrators acquiesced to the petitioners' demands but said they asked Cornyn to come back at a future date. Cornyn never appeared on campus.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. In an official press release, the university said: "We, along with Senator Cornyn, agree that the primary focus of commencement should be a celebration of academic achievement . . . [and we agreed that he should] visit with our students again at a future date in order to keep the focus on graduates and their families."

School: Texas Southern University, Thurgood Marshall School of Law
Controversy Explanation: Students claimed that Cain is racist, sexist, anti-gay, and transphobic, and the university president interrupted the event, inviting protesters who had been escorted out by campus police back into the room. He said event organizers hadn't followed proper approval procedures and that, therefore, he was cancelling the event. Organizers claim they did follow proper approval procedures.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous), Appeased Protesters. The university president told security: "Officers, let them [the protestors] in. . . .What you're seeing today is an unapproved event."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Bowser because of Bowser's views on abortion, LGBTQ rights, and physician-assisted suicide. Bowser spoke successfully.

School: University of Arkansas School of Law
Controversy Explanation: After objections to Chesler's planned lecture, titled “Violence in the Name of Honor: Confronting and Responding to Honor Killings and Forced Marriage in the West," the director of the university law school’s Center for Middle East Studies disinvited Chesler, opposing Chesler's views on honor killings and Islam. The university suspended the director for rescinding Chesler's invitation.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. A university spokesperson told reporters: "The University of Arkansas believes in the free exchange of ideas and in a balanced presentation of viewpoints and does not approve of a program director’s recent decision to cancel a presentation via Skype by Dr. Phyllis Chesler."

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Political Views
Controversy Explanation: Students demanded that the university rescind its invitation of DeVos to deliver a commencement speech because of DeVos' views on campus sexual assault. DeVos spoke successfully while protests occurred outside the venue.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The president of the university issued a statement which read: "In my letter of invitation, I afforded her [DeVos] the opportunity to use the event to not only congratulate our graduates but to also present her views on higher education issues of her choice...After reading about events at other universities where persons were denied the right to speak because some on campus opposed the views of the speaker, I became convinced that the University of Baltimore was the right institution to affirm the academy's commitment to freedom of speech."

Controversy Explanation: Administrators canceled Coulter's appearance over safety concerns, but said they would be willing to work with the student group to reschedule. Coulter appeared on campus a month later.
Public Response: Neutral. In a statement to event organizers, administrators said: "Unfortunately, UCPD determined that, given currently active security threats [there was rioting in the city of Berkeley], it is not possible to assure that the event could be held successfully—or that the safety of Ms. Coulter, the event sponsors, audience, and bystanders could be adequately protected—at any of the campus venues available on April 27th. One of the primary lessons learned here is that before a student organization commits to hosting an event on a specific date, we need to first work together to determine if a suitable venue is available at that time."

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Immigration, Political Views, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Organizers of Free Speech Week, a four-day campus event, claimed the university created bureaucratic roadblocks so they would have to cancel the event, which they did less than 24 hours before the event was scheduled to begin. The university claimed students failed to follow procedures and that the university and police department had not received sufficient notice to prepare for security. 130 professors, graduate students, and lecturers called for a boycott of classes and university events.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said: “We continue to hope that the student organization will meet its obligations and provide the campus and UCPD with the information needed to complete security arrangements. The University cannot defend spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to provide security arrangements for events based on a schedule built on a long list of unconfirmed speakers and/or a news release issued by an external commercial enterprise.”

Controversy Explanation: The Berkeley Campus Republicans and Young America's Foundation canceled an event featuring Horowitz after administrators allegedly mandated that Horowitz conclude speaking in the early afternoon, that the event be held outside of the center of campus, and be student-only to avoid complex and costly security planning. The only available venue was seven blocks from the main campus and would have cost the organizers $5,700. The university settled a subsequent lawsuit with the Berkeley Campus Republicans and Young America's Foundation, who accused the university of viewpoint discrimination.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said: "We're sorry they had to cancel it. It has nothing to do whatsoever with the speaker's perspective and everything to do with what law enforcement professionals believed needed to be done to provide a safe and secure event."

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Immigration, Political Views, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Organizers of Free Speech Week, a four-day campus event, claimed the university created bureaucratic roadblocks so they would have to cancel the event, which they did less than 24 hours before the event was scheduled to begin. The university claimed students failed to follow proper procedures and that the university and police department had not received sufficient advance notice to prepare for security. 130 professors, graduate students and lecturers called for a boycott of classes and university events.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said: "We continue to hope that the student organization will meet its obligations and provide the campus and UCPD with the information needed to complete security arrangements. The University cannot defend spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to provide security arrangements for events based on a schedule built on a long list of unconfirmed speakers and/or a news release issued by an external commercial enterprise.”

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Immigration, Political Views, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Organizers of Free Speech Week, a four-day campus event, claimed the university created bureaucratic roadblocks so they would have to cancel the event, which they did less than 24 hours before the event was scheduled to begin. The university claimed students failed to follow proper procedures and that the university and police department had not received sufficient advance notice to prepare for security. 130 professors, graduate students, and lecturers called for a boycott of classes and university events.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said: “We continue to hope that the student organization will meet its obligations and provide the campus and UCPD with the information needed to complete security arrangements. The University cannot defend spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to provide security arrangements for events based on a schedule built on a long list of unconfirmed speakers and/or a news release issued by an external commercial enterprise.”

The university claimed students failed to follow proper procedures and that the university and police department had not received sufficient advance notice to prepare for security. 130 professors, graduate students and lecturers called for a boycott of classes and university events.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said: “We continue to hope that the student organization will meet its obligations and provide the campus and UCPD with the information needed to complete security arrangements. The University cannot defend spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to provide security arrangements for events based on a schedule built on a long list of unconfirmed speakers and/or a news release issued by an external commercial enterprise.”

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Immigration, Political Views, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Organizers of Free Speech Week, a four-day campus event, claimed the university created bureaucratic roadblocks so they would have to cancel the event, which they did less than 24 hours before the event was scheduled to begin. The university claimed students failed to follow proper procedures and that the university and police department had not received sufficient advance notice to prepare for security. 130 professors, graduate students and lecturers called for a boycott of classes and university events.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). “We continue to hope that the student organization will meet its obligations and provide the campus and UCPD with the information needed to complete security arrangements. The University cannot defend spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to provide security arrangements for events based on a schedule built on a long list of unconfirmed speakers and/or a news release issued by an external commercial enterprise.”

Controversy Topic(s): Gender, Immigration, Political Views, Race, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Students who felt that Yiannopoulos is a "bigot" and "misogynist" opposed the Berkeley College Republicans' invitation of Yiannopoulos to campus. Protests outside the event turned violent, forcing the event to be canceled.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The chancellor's statement included: “While Yiannopoulos’ views, tactics and rhetoric are profoundly contrary to our own, we are bound by the Constitution, the law, our values and the campus’s Principles of Community to enable free expression across the full spectrum of opinion and perspective.”

Controversy Explanation: Elkhoury, a former member of the Israel Defense Force, was one of five members of Reservists on Duty invited to campus by two student groups, Republicans on Campus and Students Supporting Israel, to provide support and assistance to pro-Israel students on campus during "Anti-Zionism Week," an event co-sponsored by the Students for Justice in Palestine and the Muslim Student Union at the university.  Protesters disrupted the event, chanting, "From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free," and "IDF, what do you say? How many kids have you killed today?" Campus police removed the protesters from the classroom, but the protesters cotnued to chant loudly and began to use a loudspeaker to make it difficult for the audience to hear the speakers. As the event concluded, Elkhoury and his four colleagues received a police escort for their protection while leaving campus.
Public Response:
Neutral: In a student conduct review the university stated: "UCI welcomes all opinions and encourages a free exchange of ideas – in fact, we defend free speech as one of our bedrock principles as a public university.   Yet, we must protect everyone’s right to express themselves without disruption.  This concept is clearly articulated in our policies and campus messaging.  We will hold firm in enforcing it.

On May 10, 2017, an on-campus discussion sponsored by Students Supporting Israel was interrupted by shouting and chanting from a group of individuals who entered the session during the question-and-answer period.  The group left after several minutes and the event continued as planned.

UCI’s Office of Academic Integrity & Student Conduct opened a review of the incident.  The Student Conduct Officer spent weeks interviewing multiple witnesses, reviewing videos and analyzing other pertinent information, in accordance with the due process procedures found in the UCI Code of Student Conduct (https://aisc.uci.edu/policies/pacaos/code-of-student-conduct-handbook.pdf).

Based on the review, it was determined that a group of individuals organized by Students for Justice in Palestine (SJP) disrupted a portion of the question-and-answer period, in violation of university policy."

Controversy Explanation: Dolin, a former member of the Israel Defense Force, was one of five members of Reservists on Duty invited to campus by two student groups, Republicans on Campus and Students Supporting Israel, to provide support and assistance to pro-Israel students on campus during "Anti-Zionism Week," an event co-sponsored by the Students for Justice in Palestine and the Muslim Student Union at the university. Protesters disrupted the event, chanting, "From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free," and "IDF, what do you say? How many kids have you killed today?" Campus police removed the protesters from the classroom, but the protesters cotnued to chant loudly and began to use a loudspeaker to make it difficult for the audience to hear the speakers. As the event concluded, Dolin and her four colleagues received a police escort for their protection while leaving campus.
Public Response:
Neutral: In a student conduct review the university stated: "UCI welcomes all opinions and encourages a free exchange of ideas – in fact, we defend free speech as one of our bedrock principles as a public university.   Yet, we must protect everyone’s right to express themselves without disruption.  This concept is clearly articulated in our policies and campus messaging.  We will hold firm in enforcing it.

On May 10, 2017, an on-campus discussion sponsored by Students Supporting Israel was interrupted by shouting and chanting from a group of individuals who entered the session during the question-and-answer period.  The group left after several minutes and the event continued as planned.

UCI’s Office of Academic Integrity & Student Conduct opened a review of the incident.  The Student Conduct Officer spent weeks interviewing multiple witnesses, reviewing videos and analyzing other pertinent information, in accordance with the due process procedures found in the UCI Code of Student Conduct (https://aisc.uci.edu/policies/pacaos/code-of-student-conduct-handbook.pdf).

Based on the review, it was determined that a group of individuals organized by Students for Justice in Palestine (SJP) disrupted a portion of the question-and-answer period, in violation of university policy."

Controversy Explanation: The Bruin Republicans protested an administration-imposed security fee, viewing it as a tax on the group's free speech. After the lawyers for the Bruin Republicans sent a letter to the university president, the university waived the security fee and Shapiro spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said the same rules are applied for everyone: "If attendees from outside UCLA are 30 percent or below, the cost for basic security is waived. There is no additional cost to the group (even) if additional security is needed to deal with protests."

Controversy Explanation: Students claimed that by encouraging "civil discourse," the panelists were "not dealing with the reality we're facing right now" with respect to fascism. Protesters disrupted the event so substantially that it had to conclude early and be moved to another location in a more limited form.

Students claimed that by encouraging "civil discourse," the panelists were "not dealing with the reality we're facing right now" with respect to fascism. Protesters disrupted the event so substantially that it had to conclude early and be moved to another location in a more limited form.

Students claimed that by encouraging "civil discourse," the panelists were "not dealing with the reality we're facing right now" with respect to fascism. Protesters disrupted the event so substantially that it had to conclude early and be moved to another location in a more limited form.

The Bruin Republicans were split on whether to invite Yiannopoulos. They canceled his appearance following criticism by students and faculty, including a professor's open letter which stated, in part, that inviting Yiannopoulos represented succumbing to the attraction of "ill-conceived political theater that can be amusing and provocative—but is ultimately counter-productive."

Students claimed that by encouraging "civil discourse," the panelists were "not dealing with the reality we're facing right now" with respect to fascism. Protesters disrupted the event so substantially that it had to conclude early and be moved to another location in a more limited form.

Chinese students opposed the university's invitation of the Dalai Lama to speak at commencement, claiming the Dalai Lama's separatist views disrespected their homeland and culture. The students contacted the Chinese Consulate and asked it to put pressure on the university to cancel the event. The Dalai Lama spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Content of Expression. The university issued a public statement that said: “Our 2017 speaker, His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama, carries a message that promotes global responsibility and service to humanity that is of great interest to the UC San Diego community and to our students as they enter their professional lives. As a public university dedicated to the civil exchange of views, the university believes commencement is one of many events that provide an appropriate opportunity to present to graduates and their families a message of reflection and compassion.”

Controversy Explanation: The Colorado Springs AntiFascists held a "Shut down Milo Yiannopoulos" event on campus to protest The College Republicans' invitation of Yiannopoulos to campus. Some students protested but the event proceeded without any major disruptions and Yiannopoulos spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The chancellor's statement included: “I absolutely reject this type of rhetoric. The statements that Mr. Yiannopoulos has made at other campuses are clearly in opposition to the values of the University of Colorado Colorado Springs and its commitment to creating an inclusive community that welcomes all. . . . At the same time, the University of Colorado system adheres to the freedoms embodied in the United States Constitution…when a student group invites a speaker, the University of Colorado does not censor the speaker because it disagrees with his viewpoints.”

Controversy Explanation: A campus event featuring Wintrich was disrupted by protesters heckling and jeering. Wintrich was arrested for appearing to accost a woman who was also arrested for taking his speech materials during his presentation. A student was arrested for breaking a window. Wintrich did not finish his remarks.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters.  The president of the university remarked after the event: "Many of us found the comments of this particular speaker, Lucian Wintrich, to be loathsome. His main goal appeared to be to perform and provoke. Nonetheless, he was within his rights to speak on campus and express himself. . . At the same time, event organizers must also be prepared for the potential consequences of their choices, especially with respect to controversial or extreme speakers. We all share in a responsibility to help create and support respectful dialogue on our campuses, and this did not fall into that category."

Controversy Explanation: The College Republicans disinvited Romirowsky, an Israeli Defense Force veteran, from a panel discussion on anti-Americanism in the Middle East after another panelist (a professor at the university) who saw the IDF as an "occupying force in the West Bank,” protested. Romirowsky turned down an invitation to speak at a later date.

Days before a Young Americans for Freedom event featuring David Horowitz, the university attempted to hold the group responsible for all security costs deemed necessary. The university then reversed the decision to impose the proposed security fees. Students protested outside the event and some walked out at the beginning of the event, saying Horowitz was racist and anti-Palestinian. Horowitz spoke successfully.

The Carl Woese Institute for Genomic Biology at Illinois invited Watson to give a lecture, then rescinded the invitation after faculty backlash over comments Watson made in the past regarding race and intelligence.

Students interrupted Murray minutes into his talk and heckled him throughout by chanting, playing loud music, and setting off cell phone alarms. An overhead projector was also pointed at Murray, displaying an arrow with the words "white supremacist" on the screen. A university spokesperson asked for quiet and threatened "further measures," but none were taken by the spokesperson or the security guards who stood idly by. Murray finished his talk despite the interruptions.
The Cardinal Newman Society objected to the the university's invitation of Harvey to deliver a commencement speech because of Harvey's views on abortion. Harvey withdrew from delivering the speech.
Public Response: Encouraged (Approved of) Self-Censorship. The interim president stated: "We had hoped very much that he would take part in our commencement exercises, but we respect his wishes . . . To my knowledge, Paul Harvey withdrew from the invitation to be our commencement speaker for personal reasons, but has agreed to come to our campus at a later date to participate in a fund-raising activity or other event to honor his longtime friend Joe Bonansinga."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed a performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the college president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the college president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The college informed students that the play could not be performed on campus and banned the performance.

During a commencement speech, students heckled Hedges, rushed the podium, and unplugged his microphone, objecting to Hedges' anti-war views. After briefly addressing the audience on the importance of academic freedom and Hedge's right to offer his opinion, the college president suggested that Hedges end his speech early for his own protection. Hedges was then escorted off the stage by campus security guards.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. During the disruption, the president of the college took the microphone and said: "If you wish to protest the speaker's remarks, I would ask that you would do it in silence, as some were doing in the back. That is perfectly appropriate. But he has the right to offer this opinion here, and we would like him to continue with his remarks." Afterwards he told reporters: I don't apologize for the fact that I let Mr. Hedges continue to speak after he was stopped the first time and for the statement that I made to allow that to go forward. I do apologize for the fact that for all kinds of reasons this turned into not a celebration of their [the students'] achievements and a reflection on the mark they might make in the world but became really an example of, I think, just the sort of unfortunate state of our conversations in this society about war."

Controversy Explanation: A student threw a pie at Sharansky during his speech, objecting to Sharansky's pro-Palestinian views. Sharansky spoke despite the pie-throwing.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed a performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the college president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

Students and faculty petitioned the university to rescind its invitation of Santorum to deliver a commencement speech because of Santorum's negative comments about homosexuality. Some students walked out during his speech but no major disruptions occurred.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. A spokesperson reported on the Trustees reasoning as follows: “We're trying to send a message that all views are welcome here, regardless of their popularity. . . .This many not be a popular path, but if we stand for tolerance, we can’t be intolerant of anyone, and we hope all involved will keep that in mind.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society objected to the university's invitation of McLellan to deliver a commencement speech because of McLellan's views on abortion and stem cell research. McClellan spoke successfully.
Carty withdrew from delivering a commencement speech over corporate corruption concerns. Both Carty and the university claimed the decision was mutual.
Public Response: Encouraged (or approved of) Self-Censorship. A university spokesperson clarified that: “It was decided that in light of the recent developments, he [Carty] wouldn't be speaking at our commencement this year.”

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Stanton to deliver a commencement speech because of Stanton's views on abortion and his support for assisted suicide. Stanton spoke successfully.

The students objected to Ritter because of his position on the Iraq War and a possible sexual scandal involving a minor.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A college trustee said: "Whether we agree with his [Ritter's] views, or whether we like him or not, the forum is the larger issue."

The university canceled the event only days before dress rehearsal.

In an email to the campus community the university president said: “In conscience, I cannot approve of its [the Vagina Monologues] performance on the campus. The play is offensive, questionable in its portrayal of violence, and not in keeping with the respect accorded the human body in this institution’s religious tradition."

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind Matthews' invitation because of Matthews' views on abortion. Matthews spoke successfully.

Controversy Topic(s): Foreign Affairs, Criminal or Other Misconduct
Controversy Explanation: School administrators at other schools canceled Ritter's appearances due to outside complaints about Ritter's opposition to the Iraq War and possible illegal conduct with minors, but Washington College refused to disinvite him.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. A college media relations specialist stated: "As an institute of higher learning, we have a duty to provide people with different points of view. . . .[Our decision is] not an endorsement of his activities. … We're just giving him a soapbox for two hours."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The university canceled the performance.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The university canceled the performance. The university then reversed its decision following a faculty member's offer to sponsor the performance as part of a course she was teaching, which the university president considered "a legitimate exercise of academic freedom," saying that putting the play on in a classroom placed it "in a suitable environment of debate and discussion.”
Public Response: Condemn Speaker (or Artist) as Person, Appeased Protesters. The university president said that "in choosing to cancel this production we believe the sensationalism surrounding the play stood in the way of our coming together to dialogue around the issue of violence against women."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Lawrence-Lightfoot to deliver a commencement speech because of Lawrence-Lightfoot's views on abortion. Lawrence-Lightfoot spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Cellucci to deliver a commencement speech because of Celllucci's views on abortion. Cellucci spoke successfully.
Hecklers booed Heaphy into silence during a commencement speech after Heaphy's remarks about the 9/11 attacks. Heaphy was unable to finish her speech.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as Person. The university president stated that "not only thoughtful but exceedingly responsible in today's world."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of O'Connor to deliver a commencement speech because of O'Connor's views on abortion. O'Connor spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of McCollum to deliver a commencement speech because of McCollum's views on abortion. McCollum spoke successfully.

The College of the Holy Cross' women's studies department rescinded Kissling's invitation after receiving pressure from the college president and outside groups who objected to Kissling's pro-choice views and her views on gender. Kissling and the event coordinators attempted to reschedule the event but the college did not allow her to speak on campus.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Encouraged (or approved of) Self-Censorship. The college president claimed to support "free speech" but denounced Kissling's criticisms of the Church as "strident, personal, manipulative, and unfair" and added that the women's department exercised "poor judgment" when it invited her to speak.

School: Georgetown University, Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service
Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation of Pelosi to deliver a commencement speech because of Pelosi's views on abortion. Pelosi spoke successfully.
Students and faculty demanded that the university disinvite Paulin, describing Paulin's views as anti-Israel. The English department revoked the invitation.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. A university statement pointed out that the invitation had been made "in ignorance of the views that he [Paulin] has expressed. . . . [T]he English department shares the concerns expressed [by the protesters]."

Controversy Explanation: Students opposed the university's selection of Yasin as a commencement speaker because of Yasin's views on Israel and Islam. Students protested but Yasin spoke without disruption.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person.  An article reported that "University faculty and officials defended the choice of Yasin’s speech, and decried the personal attacks made on him." The only public statement was by the head of the commencement committee who said about releasing the text of Yasin's speech in advance: “It’s never happened before. . . . I don't see why it should happen this time, unless the student orator wishes to release it.”

Controversy Explanation: The university rescinded its invitation of Goodwin to deliver a commencement speech after Goodwin admitted to committing plagiarism.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Kaye to deliver a commencement speech because of Kaye's views on the status of frozen embryos. Kaye spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Kaptur to deliver a commencement speech because of Kaptur's views on abortion. Kaptur spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Mitchell to deliver a commencement speech because of Mitchell's views on abortion. Mitchell spoke successfully.

Students protested the college's invitation of Fleischer because of Fleischer's involvement with the Bush administration and the Iraq War. Many students protested during the event, and some were removed for heckling. The university stood firm in its commitment to free speech and did not take sides.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The college president said: "One of the most important functions for an institution of higher education is to provide a forum for reason, debate and discussion of controversial public issues . . ..[The university has] honored the principle of academic freedom . . . [that] includes, to be sure, the freedom of speech and it also observes the courtesy which is concomitant with that principle — that is the freedom to listen."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Panetta to deliver a commencement speech because of Panetta's views on abortion. Panetta spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Tubbs Jones to deliver a commencement speech because of Tubbs Jones' views on abortion. Tubbs Jones spoke successfully.

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Political Views
Controversy Explanation: Students and faculty protested Bush's policies, such as the "redistribution of resources toward the wealthy." At the start of commencement, the associate vice president for student affairs warned those in attendance, "Disruption, including obstructing the view or hearing of others, will not be tolerated." As Bush was introduced and walking to the podium, about 10 people stood up and turned their backs to the stage, and police escorted some of them were escorted out of the ceremony.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. An administrator said Bush was a “tireless worker in the field of education” and “a man who unified this country after the terrible events of 9/11.”

Controversy Explanation: The university administration canceled the first of two lectures by Poe after the Catholic League described her views as anti-Catholic.
The university administration canceled the second of two lectures by Poe after the Catholic League described her views as anti-Catholic.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Snelling to deliver a commencement speech because of Snelling's views on abortion. Snelling spoke successfully.

Students decried Rice's speaking invitation because of her involvement with the Bush administration and started a petition against her appearance at commencement. The event proceeded mostly without disruption.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Kirk Jr. to deliver a commencement speech because of Kirk Jr.'s views on abortion. Kirk Jr. spoke successfully.

Faculty members from the African-American studies department told local reporters they would not attend the commencement speech in protest of Giuliani's insensitivity to racial issues during his two terms as mayor of New York City. Giuliani spoke successfully over silent protests.

Students objected to Moseley's invitation, claiming Moseley was unqualified to deliver a commencement speech because he had dropped out of college to become a skier. The students lodged complaints with the university indicating they felt insulted that the university had not invited someone who had contributed more to society. Moseley spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. A university speaker search consultant said: “His message as an Olympian will really resonate with students. He’s been skiing since he was 4 years old, and has an outstanding message about dedication and setting goals.”

Controversy Explanation: The university relocated a flag that was part of a nationally touring art exhibit from a flagpole atop a university building to inside the university art museum after the governor demanded its removal. The state governor said the flag was “disrespectful” and “absolutely unacceptable." Administrators claimed they were concerned about safety because of angry tweets and a call which a police investigation found to be “more harassing than threatening.” The governor continued to press the university to destroy the flag and even offered to have the Boy Scouts burn it. The university did not take the governor up on his offer.
Public Response:
Neutral (Disingenuous), Appeased Protesters. The Office of the Chancellor issued a statement: "Over the course of the day, the conversation around this display has generated public safety concerns for our campus community. While we want to foster difficult dialogue, we cannot allow that dialogue to put our people or property in harm’s way.

We have begun the process of relocating the exhibit to the Spencer Museum of Art, where we can continue the important conversation it has generated."

Controversy Explanation: The university president received numerous emails and letters asking it not to allow Farage to debate Vicente Fox. Farage spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The university president responded to protesters in his opening remarks for the debate: “I am not so sure that we have been so successful in training you to be responsible citizens who know how to live rightly in a free society. . . .The role of a university is not to make ideas safe for students, it is to educate students.”

Controversy Explanation: Students claimed that a Turning Point USA event featuring Dave Rubin could "incite acts of racism, xenophobia, and transphobia." The event was moved from its original location because university police “had info of outside agitators” who planned to disrupt the event. At the event's new location students attempted to block people from entering the event and shouted over over Rubin during his speech. The event resumed and Rubin finished his remarks.

Students petitioned the university to disinvite Shapiro. A few days before the event, the university imposed a $5,500 security fee on the College Republicans, the hosting organization. The university waived the fee after being threatened with a lawsuit by the Alliance Defending Freedom and Shapiro spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said the decision was made to waive the fees "in light of the confusion over this issue and the difficult position the College Republicans would be in without additional funds."

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Gender, Political Views, Race, Religion
Controversy Explanation: Students and student groups objected to Shapiro's appearance, claiming he is a purveyor of hate speech, a racist, and known to have made discriminatory comments against multiple minority communities. They protested, in part, by reserving seats in the event venue in order to prevent other students from attending. Shapiro spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral. the university public safety chief told reporters: “Our role is to make sure that all parties on campus may safely exercise their First Amendment rights in accordance with university policy.”

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Police, Race
Controversy Explanation: Outside groups protested Garcetti's speech, decrying his approach to city homelessness and police misconduct. Event organizers cut the speech short, fearing for Garcetti's safety.

School: University of Southern Maine, Lewiston-Auburn College
Speaker/Performer/Title: Industrial Maine: Our Other Landscape I
Controversy Explanation: The university ordered the painting, Industrial Maine: Our Other Landscape I, and two other paintings removed from the campus art gallery after discovering that the artist is a convicted sex offender. All three paintings were removed.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. An offical university statement said: "USM received a complaint from a member of the public. The complaint was not about the content of the art, but the artist. After careful review, USM decided to remove his works from this exhibit."

School: University of Southern Maine, Lewiston-Auburn College
Speaker/Performer/Title: Industrial Maine: Our Other Landscape II
Controversy Explanation: The university ordered the painting, Industrial Maine: Our Other Landscape II, and two other paintings removed from the campus art gallery after discovering that the artist is a convicted sex offender. All three paintings were removed.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. An offical university statement said: "USM received a complaint from a member of the public. The complaint was not about the content of the art, but the artist. After careful review, USM decided to remove his works from this exhibit."

School: University of Southern Maine, Lewiston-Auburn College
Speaker/Performer/Title: Industrial Maine: Our Other Landscape III
Controversy Explanation: The university ordered the painting, Industrial Maine: Our Other Landscape III, and two other paintings removed from the campus art gallery after discovering that the artist is a convicted sex offender. All three paintings were removed.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. An offical university statement said: "USM received a complaint from a member of the public. The complaint was not about the content of the art, but the artist. After careful review, USM decided to remove his works from this exhibit."

Controversy Topic(s): Criminal or Other Misconduct, Gender, Race
Controversy Explanation: Handler withdrew from speaking at commencement after facing criticism from students and alumni for his comments on gender and race and after being accused of sexual harassment. Anita Hill, who had been invited to the ceremony as an honorary doctorate recipient, replaced Handler as commencement speaker.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship. The university president stated: “Daniel Handler has chosen to withdraw as Wesleyan’s Commencement speaker this May. . . .We've agreed that the focus of the event should be on the Class of 2018, their families and the celebration of graduation."

Controversy Explanation: The theatre department canceled a production of the play, Beast Thing, because student actors felt uncomfortable with the material and worried that the violent content might have a harmful impact on audience members. Some faculty and students also complained that the production didn't include enough actors of color.

College administrators informed George Cole, the artist and a student at the college, that he would not be allowed to enter Jesus First Bike (and The Hero) in the college's annual Student Art Exhibition becasue it depicted religious content and themes. Cole had previously won Best in Show twice, in 2009 and 2012. In both years members of the general community complained about Coles' offensive work and in 2012 called on the college to ban Cole from entering work into future exhibitions.

College administrators informed George Cole, the artist and a student at the college, that he would not be allowed to enter The Hero (and Jesus First Bike) in the college's annual Student Art Exhibition becasue it depicted religious content and themes. Cole had previously won Best in Show twice, in 2009 and 2012. In both years members of the general community complained about Coles' offensive work and in 2012 called on the college to ban Cole from entering work into future exhibitions.

McFarland, a Christian who believes tht life starts at conception, was invited to campus by Medical Students for Life, an on-campus student organization, to discuss when life actually begins at the medical school. Faculty and students objected to McFarland's invitation and the medical school's administrarion imposed substantial and excessive security fees. McFarland spoke sucessfully.

Students, faculty, alumni, employees, and members of the Native American community, called on the university to remove 12 murals depicting Christopher Columbus' voyage across the Atlantic Ocean and discovery of the Americas in 1492 from the second-floor hall of the Main Buliding because they depict Native Americans and Blacks in subservient roles.  In early 2019 the university president announced that the murals would be covered "by woven material consistent with the décor of the space." Three years later the university uncovered the murals for a week for "instructional purposes."
Public Response: Neutral.  In a letter to the campus community the university president said: "Since the 1990s, a brochure has been provided that explains to viewers the context of the murals’ composition and some of the historical reality of the events depicted. However, because the second-floor hall of the Main Building is a busy throughway for visitors and members of the University community, it is not well suited for a thoughtful consideration of these paintings and the context of their composition. We will, therefore, create a permanent display for high-quality, high-resolution images of the murals in a campus setting to be determined that will be conducive to such an informed and careful consideration. The murals on the walls of the Main Building will themselves be covered by woven material consistent with the décor of the space, though it will be possible to display the murals on occasion. I will establish a committee to decide on the place to display the images of the murals and the appropriate communication around the display. We will begin soon the making of covers for the murals."

Source(s): Administrator(s), Alumni, Faculty, General Public, Student(s)
Controversy Explanation: The Hovey Murals, located in an old, locked dining hall that is no longer in use, depict a story about a group Native Americans who are tempted to drink and then enroll at Dartmouth by the college's founder. After Native American students complained aboutthem, college administrators formed the Hovey Murals Study Group --- consisting of students, faculty, staff, and alumni --- to decide whether the murals should be removed. The  HMSV recommended the college remove the murals and they were moved to a storage location off campus, they remain accessible to faculty who want to use them in their teaching or research.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters, Condemned Expression.  In a statement the university president said: "The derogatory images in the Hovey murals convey disturbing messages that are incompatible with Dartmouth’s mission and values. Moving them off-campus to Hood storage is the right thing to do."

Controversy Explanation: A student-led online petition called on the university to remove the murals from the Zimmerman Library on campus becasuse they are "inherently racist." The petition garnered over 1,000 signatures. On the recommendation of the university president and provost, the murals were covered.

After students complained in an open forum a year earlier that they felt alienated and excluded by the murals, the university established a committee to make a recommendation to address the students' concerns. The committee recommended that the university remove the murals but preserve and archive them. The university removed the mural and established an online archive of them.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters.  In a statement a university senior vice president said: "Students have told us that they don’t want to receive awards in Alumnae Lounge because they feel excluded, and that’s important to hear. We want to attract a diversity of people to the university. But no less important, when they arrive, we want them to feel they belong here."

Controversy Explanation: About five minutes into his performance, Burress started projecting an email to the audience about the restrictions the university placed on his act, which included a ban n content involving rape, sexual assault, race and sexual orientation. He began mocking the university administrators and then made a joke about the Catholic Church's history of sexual abuse. Administrators then had Burress' mic cut off. Burress continued with his set without the mic before he was drowned out by music. He ultimately returned to the stage and made jokes about his mic getting cut off.
Public Response: Disingenuous.  A university spokesperson confirmed that Burress' mic was cut "because he violated the mutually agreed upon content restriction clause in his contract,"" and added: ""It is standard for the University to include a content restriction clause in entertainment contracts; Buress is the only entertainer to disregard the clause to the degree that his mic was cut. Buress eventually returned to the stage and completed his set."

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Boghossian, a philosophy professor at the university scheduled and moderated a discussion between James Damore (former Google engineer known for his controversial memo on gender differences in tech), Heather Heying (evolutionary biologist and critic of gender studies), and Helen Pluckrose (cultural critic and co-author of Cynical Theories), titled "We Need to Talk About Diversity." The event sought to discuss issues surrounding gender, diversity, and free speech. While the university ignored calls for the events cancellation and allowed it to proceed, it was disrupted by activists, who shut off the sound system and attempted to prevent the panelists from speaking. Video footage of the event shows demonstrators knocking over microphones and overturning sound equipment, forcing the discussion to continue without amplification.
Public Response: Honors.  The university's president stated that the university: "supports freedom of speech and academic inquiry for all its faculty and students" and that disruptions of campus events would not be tolerated.

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Damore, a former Google engineer known for his controversial memo on gender differences in tech, participated on a panel discussion at the university with Heather Heying (evolutionary biologist and critic of gender studies) and Helen Pluckrose (cultural critic and co-author of Cynical Theories). The panel was titled "We Need to Talk About Diversity," and was moderated by Peter Boghossian (a philosophy professor at the university who organized the panel) and  sought to discuss issues surrounding gender, diversity, and free speech. While the university ignored calls for the events cancellation and allowed it to proceed, it was disrupted by activists, who shut off the sound system and attempted to prevent the panelists from speaking. Video footage of the event shows demonstrators knocking over microphones and overturning sound equipment, forcing the discussion to continue without amplification.
Public Response: Honors.  The university's president stated that the university: "supports freedom of speech and academic inquiry for all its faculty and students" and that disruptions of campus events would not be tolerated.

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Race, Religion, Sexuality
