We sometimes profoundly disagree with statements of faculty, invited speakers, or other students; such disagreement and critical analysis occur regularly at our university, and we are committed to ensuring that our environment encourages and protects robust debate and inquiry.”

Speaker/Performer/Title: Damaged: The Transing of America’s Kids
Controversy Explanation: A screening of the documentary, Damaged: The Transing of America’s Kids, was cut short after student protesters disrupted a watch party for 20 minutes. Campus police entered the room and asked the protesters to leave, but the protesters continued to chant until police began escorting them out of the room.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous), Appeased Protesters. A letter from the university's Center of Equity and Student Belonging to the student group that disrupted the event said: "We strongly support Mecha’s right to speak out on important issues and to make the voices of its members heard. That is fundamental to a democratic society. As you know, we share your concern over the hurt that certain groups are causing to the university’s marginalized communities. However, the law does not permit one side of a dispute to disrupt and prevent another from peacefully speaking their mind. In the same way Mecha may have its voice heard, those with opposing views also have the right to speak and to have their voices heard even if you disagree with their offensive views."

Controversy Explanation: The university canceled an event featuring el-Kurd sponsored by the Will Miller Social Justice Lecture Series and the departments of English and sociology, citing safety and security concerns in light of conflict in Gaza. Students started a petition to have the decision reversed, but to no avail. The event was moved online.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said: "Based on conversations over the past week with community members, campus partners and public safety officials, our assessment is that holding the event on campus this week raises safety and security concerns that cannot be sufficiently mitigated. Therefore, the university has determined it will not provide meeting space for the Miller Lecture Series event on October 26."

Controversy Explanation: During the Q&A period of a panel featuring Woodson, co-organized by a faculty member and the Center for the Study of Liberal Democracy, online participants heckled, shouted, and masturbated on-camera. Students working the tech feeds turned off the online portion of the panel,  making it impossible for the online audience to continue participating.

During the Q&A period of a panel featuring Swain, co-organized by a faculty member and the Center for the Study of Liberal Democracy, online participants heckled, shouted, and masturbated on-camera. Students working the tech feeds turned off the online portion of the panel,  making it impossible for the online audience to continue participating.

During the Q&A period of a panel featuring Johnson, co-organized by a faculty member and the Center for the Study of Liberal Democracy, online participants heckled, shouted, and masturbated on-camera. Students working the tech feeds turned off the online portion of the panel, making it impossible for the online audience to continue participating.

During the Q&A period of a panel featuring Fontanilla, co-organized by a faculty member and the Center for the Study of Liberal Democracy, online participants heckled, shouted, and masturbated on-camera. Students working the tech feeds turned off the online portion of the panel,  making it impossible for the online audience to continue participating.

During the Q&A period of a panel featuring Reilly, co-organized by a faculty member and the Center for the Study of Liberal Democracy, online participants heckled, shouted, and masturbated on-camera. Students working the tech feeds turned off the online portion of the panel,  making it impossible for the online audience to continue participating.

Students petitioned the university to disinvite Stevenson from speaking at commencement because of Stevenson's leadership role in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints and the fines leveled against the group by the Securities and Exchange Commission for commiting tax fraud. Stevenson spoke successfully.

Protesters disrupted a Students for Life of America-sponsored event featuring Hawkins because of her pro-life stance. The event never began because there was so much heckling and, eventually, pushing. Two nonstudents were arrested. Instead of controlling the protesters, campus police asked the speaker to leave.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson after the event said that “VCU is committed to promoting a safe environment for our students, faculty, staff and visitors so that the right to gather and speak freely is protected. . . . We must extend dignity and respect to others, especially those with whom we disagree.”

Controversy Explanation: Multiple student organizations, including the College Republicans and College Democrats, co-sponsored a panel discussion centered on diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives including Swain (and Marc Lamont Hill). The discussion was difficult to arrange and ended up in a smaller venue than requested because of bureaucratic roadblocks which the university seemed to apply in a discriminatory manner based on the speaker's viewpoint or the political orientation of the event sponsors. Swain spoke successfully.

Multiple student organizations, including the College Republicans and College Democrats, co-sponsored a panel discussion centered on diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives including Hill (and Carol Swain). The discussion was difficult to arrange and ended up in a smaller venue than requested because of bureaucratic roadblocks, which the university seemed to apply in a discriminatory manner based on the viewpoint of the speaker or the political orientation of the event sponsors. Hill spoke successfully.

Students, faculty, and alumni wrote a letter calling on administrators to prevent Walsh from speaking on campus, objecting to Walsh's documentary, What is a Woman? Other resistance to having the Walsh event on campus included a student petition, the destruction of flyers, and a death threat. Walsh rescheduled the event, citing security concerns given recent threats at another university. Walsh spoke successfully at the rescheduled event.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The university president released a statement that included: "Our commitment to diversity, along with our commitment to freedom of expression, is also the reason we permit all recognized student organizations to invite speakers of their choosing to campus. Washington and Lee does not approve or reject events based on content, and the university does not endorse the views of any invited speaker.

Sometimes the views of invited speakers are objectionable to members of our community. But as an academic institution, our purpose is to help our students learn to examine, evaluate, and express points of view, so that they may become lifelong learners, responsible leaders, and engaged citizens. Toward this end, we provide a setting in which all ideas can be freely exchanged, discussed, and debated."

Controversy Explanation: Multiple student organizations, including the College Republicans and College Democrats, co-sponsored a panel discussion centered on diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives that Onwuka moderated. The discussion was difficult to arrange and ended up in a smaller venue than requested because of bureaucratic roadblocks, which the university seemed to apply in a discriminatory manner based on the viewpoint of the speaker or the political orientation of the event sponsors. The panel discussion was completed successfully.

A small group of protesters, upset over George's views on abortion and sexuality and his status as a board member of the Heritage Foundation, shouted and played loud music during George's lecture, "The Truth-Seeking Mission of the University," preventing George from finishing his speech. Campus security did not intervene and the college president, who was in the audience, did not request that they do so. Administrators encouraged the protesters to allow George to speak and to challenge him with questions when he completed his remarks. Nevertheless, the protesters continued disrupting and the event ended early.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous).  A college spokesperson said: “It is unfortunate that a very small group of students chose to disrupt the lecture. . . [Such disruption] is not consistent with the core values of the liberal arts to which Washington College is committed.”

Controversy Explanation: The university president canceled a student group's charity drag show because of his personal religious beliefs, calling drag shows “derisive, divisive and demoralizing misogyny.”
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. In an email to the university community the president said: “A harmless drag show? Not possible. I will not appear to condone the diminishment of any group at the expense of impertinent gestures toward another group for any reason, even when the law of the land appears to require it."

Controversy Explanation: The student government voted to reject a student group's request to invite Van Fleet to speak about her experiences growing up during Mao's Cultural Revolution, saying it was “fearful of her bringing views to campus that would be harmful or offensive.”
The university received a "barrage" of emails from unknown sources demanding that it prohibit a screening of the film, Israelism. The film was screened successfully.

Members of LionLez's board, the student group sponsoring the film screening "postponed" the event after an email from LionLez's president defended a controversial flyer promoting the event that said "It’s FREE PALESTINE over here. Zionists aren’t invited" led to "threats from a genocidal group of people." The email stated that "white Jewish people are today and always have been the oppressors of all brown people,” “WHEN I SAY THE HOLOCAUST WASN’T SPECIAL, I MEAN THAT,” and that “Israelites are the Nazis. University administrators then demanded that LionLez leadership take down its post about the event being rescheduled, because "the event has not been rescheduled and Columbia has policies and a process through which students can be disciplined for their behavior."
Public Response: Condemned Expression: A university spokesperson said: “As we have reiterated many times over the past few weeks, antisemitism or any other form of hate will never be tolerated in our community. The event organized by Lionlez is not proceeding on Friday and is being reviewed.”

Controversy Explanation: Eberstadt was invited by The Tocqueville Program to give a talk about her recently released book, “Primal Screams: How the Sexual Revolution Created Identity Politics," but withdrew after another speaker invited to campus, Scott Yenor, encountered hostile protesters when on campus, and because the university's Cultural Life Program, which requires students to attend a certain number of campus speeches, decided to deny students credit for attending Eberstadt's speech.
Public Response: Neutral: The university president said: "Ms. Eberstadt’s assumption that she would encounter a “hateful mob” at Furman is troubling. We have had no incidents of violence or disruption to any speakers. We were truly surprised by Ms. Eberstadt’s characterization of the events leading up to her decision and disappointed to learn that she had canceled. This was a missed opportunity for our students to hear from her and engage in healthy dialogue. She is, of course, welcome to return so that she may learn more about how thoughtful our students are and how they engage civilly."

Controversy Explanation: The Palestine Solidarity Committee, an on-campus student organization invited Peled to campus. A day before Peled's scheduled talk, U.S. Representative Jim Banks, who is running for Senate, wrote to the president of the university raising concerns over alleged incidents of antisemitism on campus. Banks focused on the PSC threatening to withdraw federal funding if university administrators “condone or tolerate campus antisemitism.” The PSC's faculty sponsor, Abdulkader Sinno, was then told by his department chair to cancel Peled's talk because Sinno had allegedly violated university policy by listing the department as the event sponsor. The PSC rebooked the room and Peled spoke successfully.

School: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill
Controversy Explanation: When the event was originally scheduled the student group organizing the event, Students for Life of America, were informed that they would likely pay a $224 fee for security. On the day of the event, the university assigned over a dozen police officers to the event for security, and informed Students for Life of America they would be charged $3,877.05 in security fees. The event took place and the student organizers then contacted the national office of Students for Life of America for legal assistance. The national office sent the university a letter demanding the exhorbitant security fees be reduced on the grounds that they were viewpoint discriminatory. The university agreed to drop all police related security fees and some other administrative fees as asked.

School: Harvard University, The John F. Kennedy School of Government
Controversy Explanation: Alyaha was scheduled to moderate a discussion organized by professor titled "50 Years Since the 1973 Oil Embargo: Reflections and Perspectives." The panelists included Meghan O'Sullivan, Vijay Vaitheeswaran, Edward Luttwak, and Helima Croft. During the event a group of protesters entered the room objecting to two of the speaker (Luttwak and O'Sullivan) becuase of their ties to the fossil fuel industry. The demonstrators made it difficult for the audience to see or hear the speakers. Administrators in attendance said they could not interfere with the protesters' rights to free expression.

School: Harvard University, The John F. Kennedy School of Government
Controversy Explanation: A professor organized a panel discussion titled "50 Years Since the 1973 Oil Embargo: Reflections and Perspectives." The panelists included Croft (and Meghan O'Sullivan, Vijay Vaitheeswaran, and Edward Luttwak) and was moderated by Mohammed Alyahya. During the event a group of protesters entered the room objecting to two of the speaker (Luttwak and O'Sullivan) becuase of their ties to the fossil fuel industry. The demonstrators made it difficult for the audience to see or hear the speakers. Administrators in attendance said they could not interfere with the protesters' rights to free expression.

School: Harvard University, The John F. Kennedy School of Government
Controversy Explanation: A professor organized a panel discussion titled "50 Years Since the 1973 Oil Embargo: Reflections and Perspectives." The panelists included Luttwak (and Helima Croft, Meghan O'Sullivan, and Vijay Vaitheeswaran) and was moderated by Mohammed Alyahya. During the event a group of protesters entered the room objecting to two of the speaker (Luttwak and O'Sullivan) becuase of their ties to the fossil fuel industry. The demonstrators made it difficult for the audience to see or hear the speakers. Administrators in attendance said they could not interfere with the protesters' rights to free expression.

Students protested Feder's opposition to hate crime laws and heckled him during his talk, causing him to leave the stage midway through the event. Event organizers were charged an unordinarily high security fee, yet security only removed one protester, standing by while others made it impossible for Feder to continue speaking over the commotion.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The university's executive director of news and media relations claimed that the university is committed to "open exchange of ideas . . . [and that] the police handled the situation in the room without difficulty, which included removing one person. . . . [and that it was Feder's choice to end the event]."

Controversy Topic(s): Criminal or Other Misconduct, Police, Terrorism
Controversy Explanation: Members of the New Jersey and Massachusetts Fraternal Order of Police protested Levasseur’s appearance because of his terrorist record and wanted his talk canceled. The university supported the talk, but the Libraries’ Department, which had invited Levasseur, changed its mind and revoked the invitation. Levasseur was reinvited by a different university department, but the parole board denied him permission to travel.
Public Response: Neutral. A university spokesperson said that "understanding how and why people take different paths to seek social change are important. We can learn his story and how he was motivated. I think [this] is relevant to how we grapple with the issues."

School: University of North Carolina School of Law
Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Foreign Affairs, Judiciary System, Terrorism
Controversy Explanation: Students and faculty circulated a petition against the law school hosting Mukasey as commencement speaker because of Mukasey's views on the legality of torture. The student bar association that invited Mukasey stood by their choice. Mukasey spoke successfully.

School: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill
Controversy Explanation: Students protested against Tancredo's views on immigration and the DREAM Act. Tancredo cut his speech short and left after a protester threw a rock that broke a window.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university president said: "As someone who believes in free speech to my very bones and who also strongly believes that students need to hear from knowledgeable people with very different opinions, I was deeply disappointed that congressman Tancredo was not allowed to deliver his remarks."

School: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill
Controversy Explanation: Students protested Goode's views on immigration and the DREAM Act. Tom Tancredo, another invited speaker, cut his speech short and left after a protester threw a rock that broke a window.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university president's statement included: "As someone who believes in free speech to my very bones and who also strongly believes that students need to hear from knowledgeable people with very different opinions, I was deeply disappointed that congressman Tancredo [and Goode] was not allowed to deliver his remarks."

Source(s): Activist(s), Faculty, Public Figure(s), Stakeholder(s), Student(s)
Controversy Explanation: Students, community members, and the Cardinal Newman Society criticized former President Obama's support for abortion access. A petition created by the Cardinal Newman Society with more than 300,000 signatories opposing the university's invitation of Obama to deliver a commencement speech was delivered to the university administration. Obama spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. A news report stated that Notre Dame’s president "has taken the opportunity to restate publicly his and Notre Dame’s opposition to Obama’s [positions on abortion and stem cell research].”

Controversy Explanation: A state representative introduced a resolution calling on the university to revoke Dawkins' invitation because of Dawkins' views on evolution. Dawkins spoke successfully, although the state legislature investigated the university for hosting him.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and called on its members and other concerned Catholics to encourage the university to cancel the performance. The event took place.

During a speech by Horowitz on Islamic racism and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, students who stood with their back to Horowitz were escorted out because they obstructed the view of other audience members.
Students heckled Horowitz throughout his speech on academic freedom despite administrators warning that they could be arrested.

Stein withdrew from delivering a commencement speech after the university received complaints from "persons both internal and external to the university" about Stein's opposition to the theory of evolution.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship. The university president said: "I did not ask him not to come. . . . I was not going to let him be blindsided by controversy."

Controversy Explanation: The college canceled Corvino's speaking event because of his support for gay rights.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters.  The college president stated that a "Catholic school cannot endorse a program that directly opposes church teachings."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Judiciary System, Terrorism, Other
Controversy Explanation: Faculty members sent Mukasey a letter asking him to withdraw from delivering a commencement speech at the law school, claiming his silence on waterboarding implied his support for this interrogation tactic. The university decided to have him speak but not grant him, or any future commencement speaker, the traditionally awarded Founder’s Medal, so speaking at commencement would no longer be tied to the implication that the university was honoring speakers for their views.
Public Response: Supported Content of Expression.  The law school dean said: "Their objections were based on Mr. Mukasey’s perceived position on waterboarding. I say 'perceived' because several of his public statements suggest that he is personally opposed to it. But he has declined to take a public position on the legality of the practice."

Controversy Explanation: A student disrupted a speaking event featuring Friedman by storming the stage and throwing a pie at Friedman, claiming Friedman's views on environmentalism are a "sham" because Friedman supported the use of biofuels. Friedman left the stage to clean himself off, then resumed his speech.
Students and public organizations heckled Finkelstein throughout his speech, claiming he was anti-Israel, anti-Semitic, and a Holocaust denier.
Public Response: Neutral. The university provost said, while the speaker is controversial, his talks will allow students to think about "our long-term involvement in the Middle East and about the way we respond to each other's views."

Controversy Explanation: Students and members of the general public objected to having Claiborne speak because of Claiborne's move toward a more liberal theology.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university VP for student life said that despite "a high degree of receptivity on campus to the Claiborne lecture, he decided to cancel the lecture to avoid risking conveying the wrong message about Cedarville’s doctrinal beliefs. . . . There was a tension between my desire to use this event to challenge students to take a closer look at a very important social issue, and the need to protect Cedarville’s reputation as a conservative, Christ-centered university.”

A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.
The college disinvited Franken from a speaking event, claiming it was too close to election season to host political speakers.
Public Response: Mistaken on the Law. The college's senior VP said that "it's all about making sure a balance of views is presented to students so close to Election Day. She said all three would be welcome to speak on campus -- after Nov. 4."

Public Response: Mistaken on the Law. The college's senior VP said that "it's all about making sure a balance of views is presented to students so close to Election Day. She said all three would be welcome to speak on campus -- after Nov. 4."

The Cardinal Newman Society organized a student petition urging the university to rescind its invitation of Breyer to deliver a commencement speech and not to award him the Fordham-Stein Ethics prize because Breyer wrote the majority opinion in Stenberg v. Carhart. Breyer spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. Student Affairs did not approve the performance, so the student organizers held it off campus instead.
More than 200 faculty members petitioned the university to not invite Bush to deliver a commencement speech. Bush spoke successfully.
Some students wanted the university to disinvite Bond from delivering a commencement speech because of Bond's anti-Republican rhetoric. Bond spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person.  The universities VP for communications said that the debate will always surround people who are “catalysts for change. . . .Why would we not want to have a proven civil rights leader who has spent five decades working on behalf of equality in the United States?”

A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.
University administrators banned the play, The Vagina Monologues, from campus in 2006. Students performed the play off-campus instead.
The university rescinded its invitation of Wright to deliver a commencement speech after learning of comments Wright made about 9/11 and AIDS.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The VP for university relations said that "President Bienen never characterized Dr. Wright’s views or made a judgment about them." But the university president wrote Wright, "In light of the controversy surrounding statements made by you that have recently been publicized, the celebratory character of Northwestern's commencement would be affected by our conferring of this honorary degree. Thus I am withdrawing the offer of an honorary degree previously extended to you."

School: Northwestern University Pritzker School of Law
Controversy Explanation: Students disapproved of Springer's TV show and conduct. The law school dean said he would take their concerns seriously, but he did not rescind the student commencement committee’s invitation of Springer to deliver a commencement speech.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The school's published statement included: "Mr. Springer is an alumnus who has held public office as a city council member and mayor of Cincinnati. He has had a very successful career in the news and entertainment industries. We look forward to Mr. Springer’s participation at commencement."

Controversy Explanation: The college disinvited Turbak-Berry because of Turbak-Berry's pro-choice views.

The college banned performances of the play, The Vagina Monologues, on-campus in 2006 "because its depiction of female sexuality is so deeply at odds with the true meaning and morality that the Catholic Church’s teaching celebrates." Students performed the play off campus for the second year straight.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the college president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.
Citing "outside complaints," the university told student organizers that the play, The Vagina Monologues, could not be performed on campus. Student organizers held the play off campus instead.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the college president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

The Smith College Republicans invited Sorba to give a speech on homosexuality and gay rights. About 10 minutes into Sorba's talk, protesters climbed through windows, stood in front of the podium, and loudly banged pots and pans. Uniformed police officers inside the venue did not stop the protest. A college administrator then told Sorba to leave for his own safety.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university president sent a mass email telling students: "One doesn’t have to agree with Sorba’s views — I personally find them dubious — to think this behavior [shouting down a speaker] is completely out of line."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.
Students and faculty protested the university's invitation of Thomas to deliver a commencement speech because of allegations of Thomas' sexual harassment.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university president's said that “The University of Georgia has never had, and will never have, I hope, a political litmus test for the speakers who appear at commencement or other events.”

Controversy Explanation: Ayers faced opposition due to his past militant activity. University administrators cited "safety concerns" and canceled Ayers's speech.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). An article reported that the university’s chancellor "says the cancellation was motivated only by safety concerns"

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and provided a sample letter and the contact information of the university's president on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. A local bishop also opposed the performance. The university did not cancel the performance but forbade the student organizers from fundraising and required them to host a panel after each performance that included a "sympathetic and thorough" presentation of Catholic teaching.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters, Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship, Neutral (Disingenuous). The university president said: "My decision on this matter arises from a conviction that it is an indispensable part of the mission of a Catholic university to provide a forum in which multiple viewpoints are debated in reasoned and respectful exchange—always in dialogue with faith and the Catholic tradition—even around highly controversial topics. Notre Dame’s policy on controversial events rests on the conviction that truth will emerge from reasoned consideration of issues in dialogue with faith, and that we will educate Catholic leaders not by insulating our students from controversial views, but by engaging these views energetically, in light of Catholic teachings. . . . . At the same time, others are upset at the restrictions on this performance—that there will be no fund-raising, that a panel must follow each play and include a sympathetic and thorough presentation of Catholic teaching."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

Students opposed Phyllis Schlafly's commencement speech and honorary degree because of her statements on gender, contraception, and immigration, and demanded the university rescind her invitation. Schlafly spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university chancellor stated: "Personally, I do not endorse her views or opinions, and in many instances, I strongly disagree with them. However, after further consultation with members of the University’s Board of Trustees, the University has concluded that it will fulfill its commitment to award the degree to Mrs. Schlafly. I apologize for the anguish this decision has caused to many members of our community."

Controversy Explanation: Administrators refused to display a student artist's senior art project unless she submitted a statement indicating that she had at some point suggested the repeated inseminations and possible abortions she went through to acquire the blood used in the art project never happened.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. A dean said: "[The art project bore] no relationship to what I consider appropriate for an undergraduate senior project."

Controversy Explanation: Students called for The Word, a 40-foot mural of Jesus, to be painted over while the university's president was considering whether or not to restore the mural. The president delayed his decision for a year and then decided to restore the mural.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.
Students protested Kristol's right to speak on campus and heckled him during his speech because they believed the U.S. government was complicit in the 9-11 attacks. Kristol spoke despite disruptions.

The university president vetoed the student government's approval of a mural depicting the life of the deceased Said, a Palestinian and Columbia University professor, after complaints from local Jewish community organizations that the mural contained "antisemitic" imagery. The president approved the mural a year later, after imagery depicting the character "Handala,” a Palestinian symbol of defiance, was removed.
College officials disinvited Churchill from delivering a commencement speech, fearing that Churchill's views on 9/11 would alienate students.
Public Response: Neutral. An associate dean said: “The controversies are worth it, but they take away money, and other things we need . . . We aren't strong now, we're transitioning.”

Controversy Explanation: The university president disinvited Corn because of Corn's criticism of George Bush, but Corn was reinvited to campus the following year.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the college president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.
Students heckled Horowitz throughout his speech, objecting to Horowitz' conservative views. Horowitz spoke through the constant disruptions.
Students attempted to shut down the event by throwing a pie at Horowitz, objecting to Horowitz' conservative views. Horowitz spoke despite the disruption.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university president said: "A university is at its best a forum for the open exchange of ideas and opinions. Mr. Horowitz's right to express his opinions was violated by those who disrupted his speech. . . We support the constitutional rights of free speech granted to Mr. Horowitz as well as to those who disagree with his opinions. The university does not support this inappropriate behavior."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society declared Thomas an "inappropriate speaker" for commencement and urged the college to rescind its invitation of Thomas because of Thomas' views on abortion and her support for stem-cell research. Thomas spoke sucessfully.

Students criticized the university's selection of Rodriguez as commencement speaker, objecting to Rodriguez' opposition to affirmative action and bilingual education, and they threatened to boycott commencement. Rodriguez withdrew from speaking at commencement despite administrative support.
Public Response: Neutral. A university spokesperson said: "We are a university that has always prided itself on the expression of free ideas. The sad part is people doing this [protesting and causing the speaker to withdraw] based on a book they haven't read."

Controversy Explanation: Calvin College professors opposed the college's selection of Bush as a commencement speaker because of Bush's position on torture and the Iraq War. Alumni "with more liberal political views vowed to never give another dollar or encourage their children to come" to Calvin. Bush spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral.  The college provost said: "When the White House comes calling, you're thrust into the national public eye. But we thought, What kind of a witness would it be to our students to say, 'No thanks. We can't handle your being here.'"

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society objected to the college having Clinton speak because Clinton's pro-choice position on abortion. Clinton spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral. The college vice president / general counsel told reporters: "We don't think that having Sen. Clinton here constitutes an endorsement of every position she holds currently, has held or will hold in the future."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.
